The population of Victoria was about 7.6 million, as of the 2010 Census, making it the fourth-most populous state in Australia. Victoria is roughly divided into three areas, the bigger of which is Greater Melbourne, Greater Hobart, and the smaller of which is the regions of regional Victoria.

Between 1835 and 1871 the population of Victoria was about 4 million, and in 1877, the population reached a peak of 6.5 million. From 1876 to 1913, the population declined by about 75%, and then plummeted by about 97% in the 20th century.

The largest city in Victoria is Melbourne, the second-largest is Geelong, and the third largest is Geelong, with a total population of 1.2 million people in 2017. The smallest city is Ballarat with a population of about 12,000.

The official language of Victoria is English, although some of its residents speak other indigenous languages. Greek, Italian, and

Politically, Victoria has 37 seats in the Australian House of Representatives and 12 seats in the Australian Senate. At state level, the Parliament of Victoria consists of the Legislative Assembly (the lower house) and the Legislative Council (the upper house). Victoria is currently governed by the Labor Party, with Daniel Andrews the current Premier. The personal representative of the Queen of Australia in the state is the Governor of Victoria, currently Linda Dessau. Local government is concentrated in 79 municipal districts, including 33 cities, although a number of unincorporated areas still exist, which are administered directly by the state.

The gold rush set the stage for Victoria's economic, social and political development. The gold rush brought improved transportation, communications and culture, and brought many new industries, including shipbuilding, ironworks, and machine building. In 1854 the first railway services were launched, including a Victorian railway line between Melbourne and Sydney. By the mid 1850s Victoria had become a major economic power, and in 1877 the first mass-produced steam-powered ship was launched from Melbourne. The first railway tunnel in Australia, the Great Southern Tunnel, was completed in 1859.

The gold rush was accompanied by a large influx of immigrants. A large number of immigrants arrived from Australia, from England and from Ireland. The Irish, most of whom were of Irish-Catholic background, played a major role in the Victorian gold rush. Irish immigrants were mainly from the counties of Roscommon, Laois and Leitrim. Other Irish immigrants were from County Monaghan, County Meath, County West

On 1 July 1851, writs were issued for the election of the first Victorian Legislative Council, and the absolute independence of Victoria from New South Wales was established proclaiming a new Colony of Victoria. Days later, still in 1851 gold was discovered near Ballarat, and subsequently at Bendigo. Later discoveries occurred at many sites across Victoria. This triggered one of the largest gold rushes the world has ever seen. The colony grew rapidly in both population and economic power. In ten years the population of Victoria increased sevenfold from 76,000 to 540,000. All sorts of gold records were produced including the "richest shallow alluvial goldfield in the world" and the largest gold nugget. Victoria produced in the decade 1851–1860 20 million ounces of gold, one third of the world's output[citation needed].

As of August 2010, Victoria had 1,548 public schools, 489 Catholic schools and 214 independent schools. Just under 540,800 students were enrolled in public schools, and just over 311,800 in private schools. Over 61 per cent of private students attend Catholic schools. More than 462,000 students were enrolled in primary schools and more than 390,000 in secondary schools. Retention rates for the final two years of secondary school were 77 per cent for public school students and 90 per cent for private school students. Victoria has about 63,519 full-time teachers.

Research on the abalone and rock lobster industries has generally focused on the environmental impacts, including (bio-chemical) and economic impacts, of fishing practices. This research has collected real time data on these industries since the 1970s. This information has been used to create a comprehensive set of economic impact scenarios for abalone and rock lobster, which have been used to assess their sustainability and overall impact.

Victoria is the centre of dairy farming in Australia. It is home to 60% of Australia's 3 million dairy cattle and produces nearly two-thirds of the nation's milk, almost 6.4 billion litres. The state also has 2.4 million beef cattle, with more than 2.2 million cattle and calves slaughtered each year. In 2003–04, Victorian commercial fishing crews and aquaculture industry produced 11,634 tonnes of seafood valued at nearly A$109 million. Blacklipped abalone is the mainstay of the catch, bringing in A$46 million, followed by southern rock lobster worth A$13.7 million. Most abalone and rock lobster is exported to Asia.

The most important freight operator is the freight railway operator, V/Line, which runs intermodal and residential freight services and operates rail freight services on the V/Line freight network. V/Line is owned by the V/Line Group.

There are a number of other regional freight operators, including Rail Tasmania and the Tasmanian Railways, which provides intermodal freight services in the regions. Other regional freight operators operate on a more limited basis.

Passenger rail services in Tasmania are provided by the Tasmanian Government Railways. Passenger service is provided by Tasmanian Railways, which operates passenger services under the state's own franchise from Melbourne to Hobart.

Railways in Tasmania are managed by the Department of Transport and Main Roads.

History

Early railway construction

The first railway in Tasmania was the Tasmanian Railway Company (TRC) (also referred to as the "Tasmanian Railway") which was formed in 1842

There are also several smaller freight operators and numerous tourist railways operating over lines which were once parts of a state-owned system. Victorian lines mainly use the 1,600 mm (5 ft 3 in) broad gauge. However, the interstate trunk routes, as well as a number of branch lines in the west of the state have been converted to 1,435 mm (4 ft 8 1⁄2 in) standard gauge. Two tourist railways operate over 760 mm (2 ft 6 in) narrow gauge lines, which are the remnants of five formerly government-owned lines which were built in mountainous areas.

The first European settlement in the area later known as Victoria was established in October 1803 at Sullivan Bay on Port Phillip. It consisted of 402 people (5 Government officials, 9 officers of marines, 2 drummers, and 39 privates, 5 soldiers' wives, and a child, 307 convicts, 17 convicts' wives, and 7 children). They had been sent from England in HMS Calcutta under the command of Captain Daniel Woodriff, principally out of fear that the French, who had been exploring the area, might establish their own settlement and thereby challenge British rights to the continent.

The initial settlers found little to be pleased with. The soil was poor, the substrate was sandy, and the surrounding land was barren. Most of the people of the colony died of diseases brought by the inhospitable climate. The settlers were offered little in the way of food and clothing and were forced to subsist on a diet of wild berries and wild grasses. Some

After the founding of the colony of New South Wales in 1788, Australia was divided into an eastern half named New South Wales and a western half named New Holland, under the administration of the colonial government in Sydney. The first European settlement in the area later known as Victoria was established in October 1803 under Lieutenant-Governor David Collins at Sullivan Bay on Port Phillip. It consisted of 402 people (5 Government officials, 9 officers of marines, 2 drummers, and 39 privates, 5 soldiers' wives, and a child, 307 convicts, 17 convicts' wives, and 7 children). They had been sent from England in HMS Calcutta under the command of Captain Daniel Woodriff, principally out of fear that the French, who had been exploring the area, might establish their own settlement and thereby challenge British rights to the continent.

The most famous of the Eureka Rebellion leaders, Colonel James Erskine, (not to be confused with James Erskine of the Eureka Stockades) was elected in 1856 to the Victorian Legislative Council, representing the electorate of Ballarat. He was a passionate supporter of British rule and the Empire. His reputation as a man of action was legendary, and in 1877, the Victorian Legislative Council abolished the estate tax and abolished the compulsory purchase of land for purposes of public housing.

Erskine was also a bilingual politician, fluent in English and French, and his influence can still be seen in the laws of the state today. He was the first member to be elected to the Legislative Council from outside Melbourne. He served as a Deputy Premier of Victoria from 1857 to 1858. He was also the first person to be elected to the Legislative Council of Victoria from the south of the state.

In 1854 at Ballarat there was an armed rebellion against the government of Victoria by miners protesting against mining taxes (the "Eureka Stockade"). This was crushed by British troops, but the discontents prompted colonial authorities to reform the administration (particularly reducing the hated mining licence fees) and extend the franchise. Within a short time, the Imperial Parliament granted Victoria responsible government with the passage of the Colony of Victoria Act 1855. Some of the leaders of the Eureka rebellion went on to become members of the Victorian Parliament.

The Premier of Victoria is the leader of the political party or coalition with the most seats in the Legislative Assembly. The Premier is the public face of government and, with cabinet, sets the legislative and political agenda. Cabinet consists of representatives elected to either house of parliament. It is responsible for managing areas of government that are not exclusively the Commonwealth's, by the Australian Constitution, such as education, health and law enforcement. The current Premier of Victoria is Daniel Andrews.

The most common agricultural crop is wheat (nearly 45% of Victorian farms), followed by barley, oats, and canola. The Victorian Government produces about 25,000 tonnes of wheat each year. The state is the largest producer of barley in the country. The state has a long tradition of producing quality wheat and barley-based foods, such as bread and pasta.

In 2004, the Victorian Government produced more than 27,000 tonnes of milk, approximately 7,000 tonnes of cheese, and 3,000 tonnes of butter. Victoria was also a major producer of other farm produce, including: beef, sheep, grain, and fruit. A significant portion of the state's crops are grown in the metropolitan area, including grain, vegetables, and fruit.

The Government of Victoria has a wide range of agricultural and other environmental policies, programs, and initiatives. The Victorian Department of Agriculture and Food (VDAF) coordinates the state's agricultural policies and programs. The Victorian

During 2003–04, the gross value of Victorian agricultural production increased by 17% to $8.7 billion. This represented 24% of national agricultural production total gross value. As of 2004, an estimated 32,463 farms occupied around 136,000 square kilometres (52,500 sq mi) of Victorian land. This comprises more than 60% of the state's total land surface. Victorian farms range from small horticultural outfits to large-scale livestock and grain productions. A quarter of farmland is used to grow consumable crops.

The Catholic Church became the dominant religion in the Huguenot religion, and Catholics became the largest religious group in the Huguenot culture. Religion and politics were both intertwined in Huguenot society.

Huguenot

Huguenots, also known as Huguenots, were a religious, national, and cultural group of French Protestants, originally identified with the city of Paris. The term "Huguenot" (from the French "Huguenot") comes from the Latin word "Gothic", which, in turn, comes from the Latin word "genitor", meaning father. The family name of the Huguenots was "Guerin".

Huguenot

Huguenots, also known as Huguenots, were a religious, national, and cultural group of French Protestants, originally identified with the city of Paris. The term "Huguenot" (from the

Huguenot numbers peaked near an estimated two million by 1562, concentrated mainly in the southern and central parts of France, about one-eighth the number of French Catholics. As Huguenots gained influence and more openly displayed their faith, Catholic hostility grew, in spite of increasingly liberal political concessions and edicts of toleration from the French crown. A series of religious conflicts followed, known as the Wars of Religion, fought intermittently from 1562 to 1598. The wars finally ended with the granting of the Edict of Nantes, which granted the Huguenots substantial religious, political and military autonomy.

The most likely term was Saint-Pierre, a French Christian saint who was thought to have been born in Lebanon. One of his sons, Saint-Pierre (died 837), was martyred in Jerusalem on the orders of the Byzantine Emperor Leo II.

The English phrase "Huguenot" may have been derived from the French name Hugenot, meaning "friend of God". The Huguenots were a group of French Huguenots who settled in the territory of modern-day France. They were persecuted during the reign of the Louis XIV of France for their faith. In 1215, the French King Louis XIV granted the Huguenot chief of the province of Normandy, Raymond le Grand, royal protection. This granted of protection was to be extended to all Huguenots. The Huguenot leader, Raymond le Grand, was granted the title of king in 1228.

The Huguenot leader, Raymond

A term used originally in derision, Huguenot has unclear origins. Various hypotheses have been promoted. The nickname may have been a combined reference to the Swiss politician Besançon Hugues (died 1532) and the religiously conflicted nature of Swiss republicanism in his time, using a clever derogatory pun on the name Hugues by way of the Dutch word Huisgenoten (literally housemates), referring to the connotations of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse (Confederates as in "a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss Confederacy"). Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement. In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party", so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation. The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France to those conspirators (all of them aristocratic members of the Reformed Church) involved in the Amboise plot of 1560: a foiled attempt to wrest power in France from the influential House of Guise. The move would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss. Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.[citation needed]

The first English translation was done by Richard Hooker, who served as Bishop of Oxford from 1491 to 1495. The translation was commissioned by Henry VIII and printed by John Mitchel, who was appointed Bishop of Rochester by Henry VIII in 1504. The first English translation of the Bible in the French language was made by John Wharton in 1535. According to Christopher Pelham, "English Protestants, the mass of whom were not fluent in French, had no difficulty in learning this translation, which was placed in the catalogue of the King's Library". The first translation of the New Testament in the French language was done by Pierre de Chasse, a French Protestant priest, in 1543.

By the 1500s, the French language was used in the translation of the Bible in a variety of settings, including legal work, teaching languages, literature, and the printing of books. The first printed book in French was the first edition of the Bible by John Locke, published in

The availability of the Bible in vernacular languages was important to the spread of the Protestant movement and development of the Reformed church in France. The country had a long history of struggles with the papacy by the time the Protestant Reformation finally arrived. Around 1294, a French version of the Scriptures was prepared by the Roman Catholic priest, Guyard de Moulin. A two-volume illustrated folio paraphrase version based on his manuscript, by Jean de Rély, was printed in Paris in 1487.

The city was set on fire by the royalist army in 1639 and was rebuilt by the royalists. The city and its university were burned again in 1648 by the Huguenots. The city was reconquered by the Protestants in 1650.

During the Jacobin era, Montpellier was the seat of the Château de Montpellier and the Palais de Justice.

The city was destroyed again by the French Revolution, in this case by the Jacobin leaders in 1848. The University of Montpellier, which had been established during the Jacobin regime, became independent and was placed under the control of the French National Assembly. The city was then governed by the Ministry of Education. In 1857, the city and its university were again reconquered by the French Republic and the university became a constituent part of the École nationale supérieure de Montpellier (ENSM).

The city

Montpellier was among the most important of the 66 "villes de sûreté" that the Edict of 1598 granted to the Huguenots. The city's political institutions and the university were all handed over to the Huguenots. Tension with Paris led to a siege by the royal army in 1622. Peace terms called for the dismantling of the city's fortifications. A royal citadel was built and the university and consulate were taken over by the Catholic party. Even before the Edict of Alès (1629), Protestant rule was dead and the ville de sûreté was no more.[citation needed]

The first community of Huguenots on the Cape was established at what is today the Cape Winelands. There, a group of Huguenots, including both men and women, began to settle by 1682. The population at the Cape peaked at about 600, and most of this was Huguenots. The Huguenots would then move on to settle in the Cape regions, the Franschhoek, and the Western Cape. The first Huguenot colony to be established in the Western Cape was at Stellenbosch, which was the location of the first mission in the Cape.

The settlement of the Cape lasted ten years. Two Huguenots, François Villion and Marie de la Queillerie, played a key role in the establishment of the first mission. Their arrival was the first signal to the Dutch of the need for a mission. The Huguenots would later join the Dutch in settling the Dutch West

Individual Huguenots settled at the Cape of Good Hope from as early as 1671 with the arrival of François Villion (Viljoen). The first Huguenot to arrive at the Cape of Good Hope was however Maria de la Queillerie, wife of commander Jan van Riebeeck (and daughter of a Walloon church minister), who arrived on 6 April 1652 to establish a settlement at what is today Cape Town. The couple left for the Far East ten years later. On 31 December 1687 the first organised group of Huguenots set sail from the Netherlands to the Dutch East India Company post at the Cape of Good Hope. The largest portion of the Huguenots to settle in the Cape arrived between 1688 and 1689 in seven ships as part of the organised migration, but quite a few arrived as late as 1700; thereafter, the numbers declined and only small groups arrived at a time.

The first English-speaking settlers in New Netherland, Christian Huguenots, arrived in 1624, while the Huguenots themselves eventually settled in 1632.

As of the 2006 census, the borough of Brooklyn had a population of 741,742, up from 726,921 in the 2002 census. The borough includes the northern part of Long Island City and the southern part of Coney Island.

Geography

Brooklyn sits atop a hill called Boot Hill, which is a prominent feature of the boroughs. This hill rises abruptly from the south at the northern end of Bushwick and winds down from the southern tip of Long Island City. Boot Hill is one of the highest points in the United States and is the highest point in New York City.

The borough is bordered by the boroughs of Queens (east), Manhattan (south and west), and Staten Island (northwest). The borough is a relatively flat area

Barred by the government from settling in New France, Huguenots led by Jessé de Forest, sailed to North America in 1624 and settled instead in the Dutch colony of New Netherland (later incorporated into New York and New Jersey); as well as Great Britain's colonies, including Nova Scotia. A number of New Amsterdam's families were of Huguenot origin, often having emigrated as refugees to the Netherlands in the previous century. In 1628 the Huguenots established a congregation as L'Église française à la Nouvelle-Amsterdam (the French church in New Amsterdam). This parish continues today as L'Eglise du Saint-Esprit, part of the Episcopal (Anglican) communion, and welcomes Francophone New Yorkers from all over the world. Upon their arrival in New Amsterdam, Huguenots were offered land directly across from Manhattan on Long Island for a permanent settlement and chose the harbor at the end of Newtown Creek, becoming the first Europeans to live in Brooklyn, then known as Boschwick, in the neighborhood now known as Bushwick.

The Huguenots had a long tradition of cooperation and mutual aid with Protestant settlers in the United States. They were invited to join the first Protestant mission in North America, established in 1645 in Charleston, by the Anglican Bishop of New York, William Colby. It was a very successful venture, and they were invited back in 1655, 1657, 1661, and 1668. In the course of their mission, they established churches, schools, and other institutions for the education of their children. This was a remarkable feat, for it was not until the end of the 17th century that Protestant missionaries became more widely accepted in the United States. The Huguenots were among the first to establish missions along the coasts of the Gulf and Atlantic Ocean in the 17th century. The first Huguenot mission was established in 1652 in the city of Charleston, South Carolina and continued until 1696.

The Huguenots had a long tradition

In the early years, many Huguenots also settled in the area of present-day Charleston, South Carolina. In 1685, Rev. Elie Prioleau from the town of Pons in France, was among the first to settle there. He became pastor of the first Huguenot church in North America in that city. After the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, several Huguenot families of Norman and Carolingian nobility and descent, including Edmund Bohun of Suffolk England from the Humphrey de Bohun line of French royalty descended from Charlemagne, Jean Postell of Dieppe France, Alexander Pepin, Antoine Poitevin of Orsement France, and Jacques de Bordeaux of Grenoble, immigrated to the Charleston Orange district. They were very successful at marriage and property speculation. After petitioning the British Crown in 1697 for the right to own land in the Baronies, they prospered as slave owners on the Cooper, Ashepoo, Ashley and Santee River plantations they purchased from the British Landgrave Edmund Bellinger. Some of their descendants moved into the Deep South and Texas, where they developed new plantations.

The League of Augsburg was formed in 1672, and later became the Protestant League against the Catholic League, which was a coalition against the Catholic League. Many Huguenots, as well as many other Protestants, supported William III of Orange, the League of Augsburg, and the Dutch Republic’s opposition to the French.

In 1683, William III was assassinated in his bed, the result of a series of conspiracies and political assassinations. Afterwards, Louis XIV assumed the title of King of France.

The Treaty of Utrecht

In 1683, Louis XIV and the League of Augsburg signed the Treaty of Utrecht. The treaty laid out the terms of the League’s dissolution and dissolution of the French Republic. The League of Augsburg agreed to dissolve and repeal the Edict of Nantes, expel the French, and re-establish the Dutch Republic.

This treaty was the culmination of a long-standing

Stadtholder William III of Orange, who later became King of England, emerged as the strongest opponent of king Louis XIV after the French attacked the Dutch Republic in 1672. William formed the League of Augsburg as a coalition to oppose Louis and the French state. Consequently, many Huguenots considered the wealthy and Calvinist Dutch Republic, which led the opposition to Louis XIV, as the most attractive country for exile after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes. They also found many French-speaking Calvinist churches there.

The 1620s was the peak of the Huguenot Revolution, which started in 1689 and lasted until the French Revolution of 1789. Under the leadership of Guy de Maupassant, the Huguenot Revolt was one of the most successful revolutions of the Enlightenment, especially in France, and it was the basis for the French Revolution. It was achieved with the passage of the Edict of Nantes in 1688, and the struggle lasted until the French Revolution of 1789.

The political reformers of the Huguenot Revolt

In 1689 the people of France elected Guy de Maupassant, a Huguenot from the village of Jacques-sur-Marne, to be the first King of France in over a hundred years. The King's first act was to ordain the establishment of a constitution of the kingdom, which was approved by the French Parliament in 1690. In the 1690s this constitution was

Renewed religious warfare in the 1620s caused the political and military privileges of the Huguenots to be abolished following their defeat. They retained the religious provisions of the Edict of Nantes until the rule of Louis XIV, who progressively increased persecution of them until he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau (1685), which abolished all legal recognition of Protestantism in France, and forced the Huguenots to convert. While nearly three-quarters eventually were killed  or submitted, roughly 500,000 Huguenots had fled France by the early 18th century[citation needed].

The Catholic Church in France and many of its members opposed the Huguenots. Some Huguenot preachers and congregants were attacked as they attempted to meet for worship. The height of this persecution was the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre when 5,000 to 30,000 were killed, although there were also underlying political reasons for this as well, as some of the Huguenots were nobles trying to establish separate centers of power in southern France. Retaliating against the French Catholics, the Huguenots had their own militia.

The Catholic Church in France and many of its members opposed the Huguenots. Some Huguenot preachers and congregants were attacked as they attempted to meet for worship. The height of this persecution was the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre when 5,000 to 30,000 were killed, although there were also underlying political reasons for this as well, as some of the Huguenots were nobles trying to establish separate centers of power in southern France. Retaliating against the French Catholics, the Huguenots had their own militia.

The 1620s was the decade when the Huguenot religion became active in France (notably in Picardy and Normandy). The first of these rebellions were in Picardy, while the second in Normandy. In 1621 the first of these rebellions was prompted by the arrest of the Huguenot-Brahmans priest Pierre-Antoine de Beaumont and in 1622 the second in Normandy. The third revolt was in Picardy, and the fourth in Normandy.[1]

The first rebellion in Picardy began on April 17, 1621, when the Huguenot priest Pierre-Antoine de Beaumont was arrested. He was the first of the Huguenot-Brahmans to be arrested and tried in France for his beliefs. The arrest was a catalyst for the second revolt in Picardy, which was sparked on January 27, 1622. The rebellion was a decisive blow against the Royal Government, and Beaum

By 1620 the Huguenots were on the defensive, and the government increasingly applied pressure. A series of three small civil wars known as the Huguenot rebellions broke out, mainly in southwestern France, between 1621 and 1629. revolted against royal authority. The uprising occurred a decade following the death of Henry IV, a Huguenot before converting to Catholicism, who had protected Protestants through the Edict of Nantes. His successor Louis XIII, under the regency of his Italian Catholic mother Marie de' Medici, became more intolerant of Protestantism. The Huguenots respond by establishing independent political and military structures, establishing diplomatic contacts with foreign powers, and openly revolting against central power. The rebellions were implacably suppressed by the French Crown.[citation needed]

The Catholic community in France is generally small, but, as noted above, Protestant migrants are large, and the Kingdom of Ireland has a large Catholic population in France, especially in large cities. There is also a large Irish-Catholic diaspora in Italy, Spain, Portugal, and various other countries in Latin and Central Africa.

History

Historicity

In the Middle Ages, the French Huguenots were a small minority, approximately 2.3% of the population, concentrated in Alsace and the Cévennes region. This was primarily the result of the expulsion of the Huguenots from their homeland in Normandy, but also from other parts of France. The Huguenot people were forced to build new cities of refuge, such as Poitou, Strasbourg and other cities in the south of France.

The first Huguenots arrived in France in 1593, after the Protestant Reformation had failed. Some

Approximately one million Protestants in modern France represent some 2% of its population. Most are concentrated in Alsace in northeast France and the Cévennes mountain region in the south, who still regard themselves as Huguenots to this day.[citation needed] A diaspora of French Australians still considers itself Huguenot, even after centuries of exile. Long integrated into Australian society, it is encouraged by the Huguenot Society of Australia to embrace and conserve its cultural heritage, aided by the Society's genealogical research services.

The "Huguenot Street Historic District" in New Paltz has been designated a National Historic Landmark site and contains the oldest street in the United States of America. A small group of Huguenots also settled on the south shore of Staten Island along the New York Harbor, for which the current neighborhood of Huguenot was named.

Huguenots in New York City, New York

The Huguenot Street Historic District is one of the oldest streets in the United States of America. The oldest street in the United States of America is Huguenot Street in New York City, New York, which is a part of the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) along with the rest of the district.

Huguenot immigrants did not disperse or settle in different parts of the country, but rather, formed three societies or congregations; one in the city of New York, another 21 miles north of New York in a town which they named New Rochelle, and a third further upstate in New Paltz. Amsterdam's population would increase to around 4.5 million by 1710. The Huguenot refugees, however, could not participate in any political activity in the Dutch Republic, as they were considered fugitives and were forced to live in hiding. The fleeing Huguenots were divided into various groups according to their religious beliefs. This religious divide was not based on national origin, as Huguenots from the Netherlands were considered Belgians.

Paganism

Paganism was a major influence in the early history of the Dutch Republic. And in particular, in the town of Antwerp. In the 17th and early 18th centuries, Antwerp became the capital of the Huguenots. The people of Antwerp and the surrounding area were among the most devout and best-educated in Europe. The Huguenots were the first to use the scientific term "paganism" to describe their beliefs. The term was a translation of the

After the revocation of the Edict of Nantes, the Dutch Republic received the largest group of Huguenot refugees, an estimated total of 75,000 to 100,000 people. Amongst them were 200 clergy. Many came from the region of the Cévennes, for instance, the village of Fraissinet-de-Lozère. This was a huge influx as the entire population of the Dutch Republic amounted to ca. 2 million at that time. Around 1700, it is estimated that nearly 25% of the Amsterdam population was Huguenot.[citation needed] In 1705, Amsterdam and the area of West Frisia were the first areas to provide full citizens rights to Huguenot immigrants, followed by the Dutch Republic in 1715. Huguenots intermarried with Dutch from the outset.

The custom of having a Saint named Huguon, and of having a black lantern in the door of the church, and of having the same in the church, was very ancient, as is evident from the usual saying of the Catholiques of Tours, that they light a Saint's lantern on Huguon, and call it the black lantern, to prevent it from going out. This happened in Tours, in the days of the King of France, and we believe it to have been the custom of the King of France.

The saint's birthplace is also mentioned by the French historian, Jean Guillaume de Chavigny, in his Histoire de l'Angleterre (Paris, 1707). This shows that Huguon was a popular saint in France. The best-known and most striking of Huguon's miracles is the reappearance of his body and soul after he had been killed at the Battle of Tours in 1470. Some

In this last connection, the name could suggest the derogatory inference of superstitious worship; popular fancy held that Huguon, the gate of King Hugo, was haunted by the ghost of le roi Huguet (regarded by Roman Catholics as an infamous scoundrel) and other spirits, who instead of being in Purgatory came back to harm the living at night. It was in this place in Tours that the prétendus réformés ("these supposedly 'reformed'") habitually gathered at night, both for political purposes, and for prayer and singing psalms. The refugee community became a functioning community in the 19th century. The Weavers, a large, rich residential house, and a large school, were built in the late 17th century as houses of worship in the parish of Whitford, which extended to Kentish Town. It was not until 1641 that there were three refugee congregations in Canterbury, and then only one with a church in its midst. The Weavers' Hall was built in 1697, and the Weavers' School in 1702. The Weavers' Hall was the site of a reconstruction of the Weavers' School in the 18th century, and the Weavers' School became a school for boys. Two of the houses in the parish of Whitford were converted into houses of refuge for refugees. The two houses in Whitford, the Weavers' and the Weavers' Hall, were rebuilt as houses of refuge and education for refugees.

Other evidence of the Walloons and Huguenots in Canterbury includes a block of houses in Turnagain Lane, where weavers' windows survive on the top floor, as many Huguenots worked as weavers. The Weavers, a half-timbered house by the river, was the site of a weaving school from the late 16th century to about 1830. (It has been adapted as a restaurant—see illustration above. The house derives its name from a weaving school which was moved there in the last years of the 19th century, reviving an earlier use.) Others refugees practised the variety of occupations necessary to sustain the community as distinct from the indigenous population. Such economic separation was the condition of the refugees' initial acceptance in the City. They also settled elsewhere in Kent, particularly Sandwich, Faversham and Maidstone—towns in which there used to be refugee churches.

The most famous Huguenot in Ireland is, of course, Bishop Pierre de La Tour, better known as the "Mad Monk", who founded the Church of Notre Dame de Paris in 1698 and served as the bishop of the new diocese of Dublin.

The Huguenot’s presence in Ireland is best illustrated by the name of their first town, Dingle. A French settlement in the area, Dingle was founded by Huguenot Cathars in the 12th century and was originally a small trading post. It was heavily damaged by the Fire of 1666, however, and became a French colony for a short time. The name Dingle itself was adopted by the Irish, and the people of Dingle were known as "Dingle people".

The first Huguenot bishops in Ireland were John Dupre, Bishop of Ballinamallard, who was born in Dingle in 1571 and died in Dingle in

A number of Huguenots served as mayors in Dublin, Cork, Youghal and Waterford in the 17th and 18th centuries. Numerous signs of Huguenot presence can still be seen with names still in use, and with areas of the main towns and cities named after the people who settled there. Examples include the Huguenot District and French Church Street in Cork City; and D'Olier Street in Dublin, named after a High Sheriff and one of the founders of the Bank of Ireland. A French church in Portarlington dates back to 1696, and was built to serve the significant new Huguenot community in the town. At the time, they constituted the majority of the townspeople.

The population of Acadia and New France did not stabilize until the 17th century, when large groups of Huguenots settled there. The colony of Acadia (now Nova Scotia), while still predominantly Catholic, had become a majority-French colony by the mid-17th century, and New France became a majority-Huguenot colony by the 17th century. The French Crown did not collect taxes from the colonists until 1673, and did not grant non-Catholics the right to settle in New France until 1691.

The bilingual French-English Charter of 1689 stipulated that the French Crown would not interfere with religious freedom. However, the Quebec Charter of 1697 stipulated that, under the authority of royal authority, Catholics would be prohibited from having property, holding public office, or from using the French language in public. In addition, Catholic titles and other civil and military titles were rendered invalid.

The British Royal Government, recognizing that the

The exodus of Huguenots from France created a brain drain, as many Huguenots had occupied important places in society. The kingdom did not fully recover for years. The French crown's refusal to allow non-Catholics to settle in New France may help to explain that colony's slow rate of population growth compared to that of the neighbouring British colonies, which opened settlement to religious dissenters. By the time of the French and Indian War (the North American front of the Seven Years' War), a sizeable population of Huguenot descent lived in the British colonies, and many participated in the British defeat of New France in 1759-60.

The Catholic states, which had generally been on good terms with Protestant France, were outraged by the edict, while the Protestants remained neutral. The Catholic states made peace with Protestant France in 1604, and in 1606 signed a treaty with the Spanish monarchy to share the control of the French Crown.

Between 1615 and 1618 the treaty between France and Spain achieved a period of peace. Between 1614 and 1618, the French territories in the Netherlands, Holland, and Flanders were decisively won by the Spanish. On 5 June 1618, a treaty was signed between the French and the Spanish in which the latter granted French titles to the Spanish Netherlands. The treaty was followed by the Treaty of Las Navas, which concluded the French and Spanish Armies of Europe.

The Treaty of Utrecht, signed in 1619, offered French titles to parts of the Spanish Netherlands and the Dutch provinces of Utrecht and Utrecht-Zuid. It also

The pattern of warfare, followed by brief periods of peace, continued for nearly another quarter-century. The warfare was definitively quelled in 1598, when Henry of Navarre, having succeeded to the French throne as Henry IV, and having recanted Protestantism in favour of Roman Catholicism, issued the Edict of Nantes. The Edict reaffirmed Catholicism as the state religion of France, but granted the Protestants equality with Catholics under the throne and a degree of religious and political freedom within their domains. The Edict simultaneously protected Catholic interests by discouraging the founding of new Protestant churches in Catholic-controlled regions.[citation needed]

The Catholic community became the most powerful in the country, and the religion became the dominant culture (notwithstanding the presence of Protestants). The Huguenot community became the most powerful in the country, and the religion became the dominant culture (notwithstanding the presence of Protestants). It was not until 1689 that Catholic emigration to the North American colonies, and then to Europe, ceased.

Revocation of the Edict of Nantes

On January 15, 1689, the French parliament, the National Assembly, passed an edict forbidding bilingual schools, which were seen as Protestant indoctrination. In the same day, the Parliament passed an edict forbidding Protestant services and requiring education of Catholics as Protestants. It proved disastrous to the Huguenots and costly for France. It precipitated civil bloodshed, ruined commerce, and resulted in the illegal flight from the country of hundreds of thousands of Protestants, many of whom became intellectuals, doctors and business leaders in Britain as

The revocation forbade Protestant services, required education of children as Catholics, and prohibited emigration. It proved disastrous to the Huguenots and costly for France. It precipitated civil bloodshed, ruined commerce, and resulted in the illegal flight from the country of hundreds of thousands of Protestants, many of whom became intellectuals, doctors and business leaders in Britain as well as Holland, Prussia, and South Africa. Four thousand emigrated to the North American colonies, where they settled in New York and Virginia, especially. The English welcomed the French refugees, providing money from both government and private agencies to aid their relocation. Those Huguenots who stayed in France became Catholics and were called "new converts".

The first English-speaking Huguenot settlers, Christian Huguenots, arrived in the New World in 1570. The colony of New France (in present-day Canada), was founded by Huguenot settlers from the New World. The first European settlers, English Huguenots, arrived in the New World in 1570. The colony of New France (in present-day Canada), was founded by Huguenot settlers from the New World. The settlement established by Huguenots in the New World was named St. Anne. This settlement was the first Protestant settlement in North America.[citation needed]

The first Protestant settlers, English Huguenots, arrived in the New World in 1570. The colony of New France (in present-day Canada), was founded by Huguenot settlers from the New World. The settlement established by Huguenots in the New World was named St. Anne. This settlement was the

The first Huguenots to leave France sought freedom from persecution in Switzerland and the Netherlands.[citation needed] A group of Huguenots was part of the French colonisers who arrived in Brazil in 1555 to found France Antarctique. A couple of ships with around 500 people arrived at the Guanabara Bay, present-day Rio de Janeiro, and settled in a small island. A fort, named Fort Coligny, was built to protect them from attack from the Portuguese troops and Brazilian Native Americans. It was an attempt to establish a French colony in South America. The fort was destroyed in 1560 by the Portuguese, who captured part of the Huguenots. The Portuguese threatened the prisoners with death if they did not convert to Catholicism. The Huguenots of Guanabara, as they are now known, produced a declaration of faith to express their beliefs to the Portuguese. This was their death sentence. This document, the Guanabara Confession of Faith, became the first Protestant confession of faith in the whole of the Americas.[citation needed]

The most famous Huguenot wine on the market today is the "Merlot" (not to be confused with the famous Merlot grape of California) of South Africa, which was originally called "Merlot du Vierge", after the Huguenots who settled there in the 16th century and made the wine. The wine is based on a blend of 75% Merlot and 25% Cabernet Sauvignon, and has a medium body with notes of black cherry, spice, and toasted nuts. The wine has a medium to full body, and is best served at room temperature.

There are many other brands of Merlot, from the larger producers in France, to the small producers in South Africa, to several small producers in the United States, and to a number of smaller producers in Spain and England.

Many of the farms in the Western Cape province in South Africa still bear French names. Many families, today mostly Afrikaans-speaking, have surnames indicating their French Huguenot ancestry. Examples include: Blignaut, Cilliers, de Klerk (Le Clercq), de Villiers, du Plessis, Du Preez (Des Pres), du Randt (Durand), du Toit, Duvenhage(Du Vinage), Franck, Fouche, Fourie (Fleurit), Gervais, Giliomee (Guilliaume), Gous/Gouws (Gauch), Hugo, Jordaan (Jourdan), Joubert, Kriek, Labuschagne (la Buscagne), le Roux, Lombard, Malan, Malherbe, Marais, Maree, Minnaar (Mesnard), Nel (Nell),Naude', Nortje (Nortier), Pienaar (Pinard), Retief (Retif), Rossouw (Rousseau), Taljaard (Taillard), TerBlanche, Theron, Viljoen (Villion) and Visagie (Visage). The wine industry in South Africa owes a significant debt to the Huguenots, some of whom had vineyards in France, or were brandy distillers, and used their skills in their new home.

It is possible that this was because of their reliance on the East Midlands lace trade. According to a 1689 document in the East Midlands, the lace trade directories stated that "the furniture of the country is of this country", therefore, it is likely that the refugees settled in Bedfordshire in order to use the East Midlands lace trade as a source of furniture.

The settlement of Huguenots in Bedfordshire was met with a great deal of controversy, which is evident from several contemporary writings in the period. In 1690, the population of Bedfordshire was around 14,000, indicating that there were around 7,000 Huguenot refugees. The first reference to Huguenot refugees in

Some Huguenots settled in Bedfordshire, one of the main centres of the British lace industry at the time. Although 19th century sources have asserted that some of these refugees were lacemakers and contributed to the East Midlands lace industry, this is contentious. The only reference to immigrant lacemakers in this period is of twenty-five widows who settled in Dover, and there is no contemporary documentation to support there being Huguenot lacemakers in Bedfordshire. The implication that the style of lace known as 'Bucks Point' demonstrates a Huguenot influence, being a "combination of Mechlin patterns on Lille ground", is fallacious: what is now known as Mechlin lace did not develop until first half of the eighteenth century and lace with Mechlin patterns and Lille ground did not appear until the end of the 18th century, when it was widely copied throughout Europe.

The Huguenots had a profound effect on European Christian culture. They were the first to create a visible presence in the culture of the European cities they settled in, and they established a firm grasp on the language of the Christian churches they chose to join. They were also the first to establish a recognizable Christian identity with regard to religious, social, and cultural issues. In 1689, in the midst of the French Revolution, a movement arose throughout Europe, called the Huguenots, whose followers tried to continue to live their lives as Christians in a bilingual society, in which the French language was the language of the church.

The Huguenots founded new congregations in Frankfurt, Berlin, Hamburg, Hamburg, and Stockholm. Most of these congregations were later to become part of the Christian Church of Sweden. Their influence was particularly strong in Berlin, where many Germans settled in the years following the French Revolution.

The Huguenots had a profound effect

In Berlin, the Huguenots created two new neighbourhoods: Dorotheenstadt and Friedrichstadt. By 1700, one-fifth of the city's population was French speaking. The Berlin Huguenots preserved the French language in their church services for nearly a century. They ultimately decided to switch to German in protest against the occupation of Prussia by Napoleon in 1806-07. Many of their descendents rose to positions of prominence. Several congregations were founded, such as those of Fredericia (Denmark), Berlin, Stockholm, Hamburg, Frankfurt, Helsinki, and Emden.

The French Revolution, which had begun in 1789, was a complex and turbulent moment in French history. The Kingdom of France was weakened by internal strife and foreign wars, and many Frenchmen were dissatisfied with the political system and its clergy. The Revolution’s supporters were divided, and many revolutionaries’ demands were unclear. Some, such as the Jacobins, advocated a complete revamp of the French political system. Others, such as the Bonapartes, advocated the creation of a dictatorship, complete with a monarchy. The Revolution was also marked by a series of violent events, including the Jacobin assassination of Louis XVI and the execution of the Bonaparte family.

The French Revolution was one of the most important social revolutions in history. Although it played no direct role in the Civil War, it had a profound effect on the United States.

After this, Huguenots (with estimates ranging from 200,000 to 1,000,000) fled to surrounding Protestant countries: England, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Norway, Denmark, and Prussia — whose Calvinist Great Elector Frederick William welcomed them to help rebuild his war-ravaged and underpopulated country. Following this exodus, Huguenots remained in large numbers in only one region of France: the rugged Cévennes region in the south. In the early 18th century, a regional group known as the Camisards who were Huguenots rioted against the Catholic Church in the region, burning churches and killing clergy. It took French troops years to hunt down and destroy all the bands of Camisards, between 1702 and 1709.

The French population at the time consisted of about 100, and most of them were Huguenots who had fled the Spanish persecution in France. The fort was built in the woods, and the first colonists arrived on September 15, 1564. They were led by Jean Ribault, who had been raised by his uncle, Jean de Ribault, in the town of St.-Ouen in Normandy.

The settlement was small, but Jean Ribault and his men managed to make it through the winter. They built a fort on the St. Johns River, which were the only two navigable rivers in the area at the time. The French were forced to live in a very primitive way, and there were no schools or churches.

In 1564 a group of Norman Huguenots under the leadership of Jean Ribault established the small colony of Fort Caroline on the banks of the St. Johns River in what is today Jacksonville, Florida. The effort was the first at any permanent European settlement in the present-day continental United States, but survived only a short time. A September 1565 French naval attack against the new Spanish colony at St. Augustine failed when its ships were hit by a hurricane on their way to the Spanish encampment at Fort Matanzas. Hundreds of French soldiers were stranded and surrendered to the numerically inferior Spanish forces led by Pedro Menendez. Menendez proceeded to massacre the defenseless Huguenots, after which he wiped out the Fort Caroline garrison.

Ribault and de Laudonnière were hanged for treason.

In 1567, Gaimard de la Chappelle, a merchant of Paris and physician, founded the colony of Saint-Jean-de-la-Plaine in the present-day state of Florida, where he founded a mission and built a school. A second mission, Saint-Jean-de-la-Côte, was established in 1569. In 1572, the first French court settlement appeared in what is now Miami, Florida. The first French colonists came from Saint-Jean-de-la-Plaine and Saint-Jean-de-la-Côte, and from the colony of Saint-Barthélémy. They settled in what is now Miami and Fort Lauderdale, and were later joined by other French settlers and Huguenots from the Caribbean.

French Huguenots made two attempts to establish a haven in North America. In 1562, naval officer Jean Ribault led an expedition that explored Florida and the present-day Southeastern U.S., and founded the outpost of Charlesfort on Parris Island, South Carolina. The Wars of Religion precluded a return voyage, and the outpost was abandoned. In 1564, Ribault's former lieutenant René Goulaine de Laudonnière launched a second voyage to build a colony; he established Fort Caroline in what is now Jacksonville, Florida. War at home again precluded a resupply mission, and the colony struggled. In 1565 the Spanish decided to enforce their claim to La Florida, and sent Pedro Menéndez de Avilés, who established the settlement of St. Augustine near Fort Caroline. Menéndez' forces routed the French and executed most of the Protestant captives.

The French community became a functioning community in the 19th century. In 1864, the French Revolutionary Army captured Manakin and burned it to the ground. Many of the Huguenots were killed or enslaved by the Union Army. The settlement remained abandoned until the early 20th century, when it was fully restored and named Manakin, Virginia. Manakin is now a town in Powhatan County, Virginia, United States.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Manakin was a major coal mining town. It was a bilingual community, with English and French speakers, as well as a large German and German-American population. In the 1960s, the town was home to the Manakin Post Office, which was closed in the 1980s. Manakin is now a historic district with many buildings dating from the 1720s to the 1930s, including the Manakin Hall, built in 1725, which is the oldest Greek-American-style

In 1700 several hundred French Huguenots migrated from England to the colony of Virginia, where the English Crown had promised them land grants in Lower Norfolk County. When they arrived, colonial authorities offered them instead land 20 miles above the falls of the James River, at the abandoned Monacan village known as Manakin Town, now in Powhatan County. Some settlers landed in present-day Chesterfield County. On 12 May 1705, the Virginia General Assembly passed an act to naturalise the 148 Huguenots still resident at Manakintown. Of the original 390 settlers in the isolated settlement, many had died; others lived outside town on farms in the English style; and others moved to different areas. Gradually they intermarried with their English neighbors. Through the 18th and 19th centuries, descendants of the French migrated west into the Piedmont, and across the Appalachian Mountains into the West of what became Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, and other states. In the Manakintown area, the Huguenot Memorial Bridge across the James River and Huguenot Road were named in their honor, as were many local features, including several schools, including Huguenot High School.

The Dutch Republic became a functioning state in 1609, when the Dutch crown ceded the Netherlands to the English Kingdom of England. The Huguenot colonies became part of the established Dutch Republic. The Huguenot exiles continued to make their way to the Dutch Republic, where they found a safe haven and political refuge. A few Huguenot exiles managed to stay in the Netherlands, such as the Huguenot William de la Motte. The Huguenot exiles in the Netherlands became a prominent part of the Dutch public life, especially after the French Revolution, when they were the leading members of the Dutch Reformed Church. The Huguenots were among the leading voices of resistance to the French Revolution and the French Revolution of 1789, and they played an important role in the French Revolution and the French Revolution of 1793. The Huguenots and their descendants became well known throughout the world.

Some Huguenots fought in the Low Countries alongside the Dutch against Spain during the first years of the Dutch Revolt (1568–1609). The Dutch Republic rapidly became a destination for Huguenot exiles. Early ties were already visible in the "Apologie" of William the Silent, condemning the Spanish Inquisition, which was written by his court minister, the Huguenot Pierre L'Oyseleur, lord of Villiers. Louise de Coligny, daughter of the murdered Huguenot leader Gaspard de Coligny, married William the Silent, leader of the Dutch (Calvinist) revolt against Spanish (Catholic) rule. As both spoke French in daily life, their court church in the Prinsenhof in Delft held services in French. The practice has continued to the present day. The Prinsenhof is one of the 14 active Walloon churches of the Dutch Reformed Church. The ties between Huguenots and the Dutch Republic's military and political leadership, the House of Orange-Nassau, which existed since the early days of the Dutch Revolt, helped support the many early settlements of Huguenots in the Dutch Republic's colonies. They settled at the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa and New Netherland in North America.

Following the French Crown's revocation of the Edict of Nantes, many Huguenots settled in Ireland in the late 17th and early 18th centuries, encouraged by an act of parliament for Protestants' settling in Ireland. Huguenot regiments fought for William of Orange in the Williamite war in Ireland, for which they were rewarded with land grants and titles, many settling in Dublin. Significant Huguenot settlements were in Dublin, Cork, Portarlington, Lisburn, Waterford and Youghal. Smaller settlements, which included Killeshandra in County Cavan, contributed to the expansion of flax cultivation and the growth of the Irish linen industry.

The Condé family was the largest Huguenot Christian family in France. The Condés were rich merchants, who owned a large number of banks and made large loans to other businesses as well as to the Huguenots. Their largest clientele were merchants who purchased goods from the Condé’s glass-making works, which were located in the northern part of the principality. The glass works were the largest employer in the principality, employing around 6,000 people. The works are known to be the oldest in France, dating back to 1604. The town of Princesse d'Enghien was founded by the family in the mid-17th century.

The Huguenot community in France was confronted by the French Revolution. The Catholic Revolutionaries were prepared to persecute the Huguenots, and the Condé family was targeted and forced to flee to the United States. The family settled in Pennsylvania, where they were

Prince Louis de Condé, along with his sons Daniel and Osias,[citation needed] arranged with Count Ludwig von Nassau-Saarbrücken to establish a Huguenot community in present-day Saarland in 1604. The Count supported mercantilism and welcomed technically skilled immigrants into his lands, regardless of their religion. The Condés established a thriving glass-making works, which provided wealth to the principality for many years. Other founding families created enterprises based on textiles and such traditional Huguenot occupations in France. The community and its congregation remain active to this day, with descendants of many of the founding families still living in the region. Some members of this community emigrated to the United States in the 1890s.

The bulk of Huguenot émigrés relocated to Protestant European nations such as England, Wales, Scotland, Denmark, Sweden, Switzerland, the Dutch Republic, the Electorate of Brandenburg and Electorate of the Palatinate in the Holy Roman Empire, the Duchy of Prussia, the Channel Islands, and Ireland. They also spread beyond Europe to the Dutch Cape Colony in South Africa, the Dutch East Indies, the Caribbean, and several of the English colonies of North America, and Quebec, where they were accepted and allowed to worship freely. History

The Huguenot tradition was rooted in the French medieval church, according to historian Claude Lévi-Strauss. From there, the tradition spread to Huguenots in France, in the rest of Europe, and even as far as Asia.

The Huguenots were a group of people who fled to France in the 16th century, fleeing religious persecution by the Catholic Church. Their arrival in France, in particular the city of Paris, was a cause of great excitement and interest, with many people gathering to celebrate their arrival.

The Huguenot people were a diverse group of people of various origins, including Huguenots from Spain and Portugal, Huguenots from Provence, Huguenots from Germany, Huguenots from Brittany, Huguenots from Normandy,

Some disagree with such double or triple non-French linguistic origins, arguing that for the word to have spread into common use in France, it must have originated in the French language. The "Hugues hypothesis" argues that the name was derived by association with Hugues Capet, king of France, who reigned long before the Reformation. He was regarded by the Gallicans and Protestants as a noble man who respected people's dignity and lives. Janet Gray and other supporters of the hypothesis suggest that the name huguenote would be roughly equivalent to little Hugos, or those who want Hugo.

The French community became a topic of interest on the European Christian scene during the Protestant Reformation (1517–1535). The first to do so was Martin Luther (1517–1545), who published his "Wissenschaftliche Syntagma zum Geist und Kirche" (1520), in which he stated that his views on justification and salvation were well established, and that the church should be reformed. For Luther, the Reformation was not a mere matter of religious freedom; rather, it was a change in the way the Church was governed. Meanwhile, the Reformed church became more and more influential in Europe. In the Netherlands, the Reformed church dominated the Reformed community. In England, the Reformed church was in the ascendancy, being the dominant force for legal reform. In the Netherlands, the Reformed church strengthened the Confession of 1559, which showed its Calvinistic influence. In Germany, the Reformed church

Other predecessors of the Reformed church included the pro-reform and Gallican Roman Catholics, such as Jacques Lefevre (c. 1455–1536). The Gallicans briefly achieved independence for the French church, on the principle that the religion of France could not be controlled by the Bishop of Rome, a foreign power. During the Protestant Reformation, Lefevre, a professor at the University of Paris, published his French translation of the New Testament in 1523, followed by the whole Bible in the French language in 1530. William Farel was a student of Lefevre who went on to become a leader of the Swiss Reformation, establishing a Protestant government in Geneva. Jean Cauvin (John Calvin), another student at the University of Paris, also converted to Protestantism. Long after the sect was suppressed by Francis I, the remaining French Waldensians, then mostly in the Luberon region, sought to join William Farel, Calvin and the Reformation, and Olivetan published a French Bible for them. The French Confession of 1559 shows a decidedly Calvinistic influence. Sometime between 1550 and 1580, members of the Reformed church in France came to be commonly known as Huguenots.[citation needed]

The Catholic community in the Netherlands was also on the defensive. The Catholic Church had been ousted from the Netherlands in 1648 and remained weakened to some degree until the Dutch Reformation, which overthrew the Catholic monopoly of the church.

During the early years of the Dutch Reformation, the Catholic Church attempted to reinstate itself with the support of the Dutch Parliament. In 1652, the Statute of Aragon was enacted, which prohibited the use of the Dutch language, the use of the Dutch flag, and the wearing of the Dutch coat of arms on clothing, jewelry, and hats without the permission of the government. The Statute also prohibited the use of the Dutch language in the civil administration. Catholics were also prohibited from holding office in the civil and ecclesiastical courts.

In what became known as the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre of 24 August – 3 October 1572, Catholics killed thousands of Huguenots in Paris. Similar massacres took place in other towns in the weeks following. The main provincial towns and cities experiencing the Massacre were Aix, Bordeaux, Bourges, Lyons, Meaux, Orleans, Rouen, Toulouse, and Troyes. Nearly 3,000 Protestants were slaughtered in Toulouse alone. The exact number of fatalities throughout the country is not known. On 23–24 August, between about 2,000 and 3,000 Protestants were killed in Paris and between 3,000 and 7,000 more in the French provinces. By 17 September, almost 25,000 Protestants had been massacred in Paris alone. Beyond Paris, the killings continued until 3 October. An amnesty granted in 1573 pardoned the perpetrators.[citation needed]

Louis XIV gained the throne in 1643 and acted increasingly aggressively to force the Huguenots to convert. At first he sent missionaries, backed by a fund to financially reward converts to Catholicism. Then he imposed penalties, closed Huguenot schools and excluded them from favored professions. Escalating, he instituted dragonnades, which included the occupation and looting of Huguenot homes by military troops, in an effort to forcibly convert them. In 1685, he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau, revoking the Edict of Nantes and declaring Protestantism illegal.[citation needed]

The first community meeting was held on May 23, 1609, at "The Burial Ground" in New Rochelle and was attended by some of the most prominent leaders of the community as well as many Huguenot refugees from the French Revolution. The first reported church, St. John's Episcopal Church, was erected on the site of the present church. On June 16, 1611, the first recorded mass was celebrated at the church, and on January 15, 1613, the first service was held at the new church. In 1616, a new stone church was erected, and the first vestibule was built in 1621, with the addition of an organ in the same year. The church, however, was not completed until 1633, and in 1634, a stone chapel was added for the use of the Huguenots. On November 20, 1632, the first male Huguenot was buried in the graveyard, and this was followed

New Rochelle, located in the county of Westchester on the north shore of Long Island Sound, seemed to be the great location of the Huguenots in New York. It is said that they landed on the coastline peninsula of Davenports Neck called "Bauffet's Point" after traveling from England where they had previously taken refuge on account of religious persecution, four years before the revocation of the Edict of Nantes. They purchased from John Pell, Lord of Pelham Manor, a tract of land consisting of six thousand one hundred acres with the help of Jacob Leisler. It was named New Rochelle after La Rochelle, their former strong-hold in France. A small wooden church was first erected in the community, followed by a second church that built of stone. Previous to the erection of it, the strong men would often walk twenty-three miles on Saturday evening, the distance by the road from New Rochelle to New York, to attend the Sunday service. The church was eventually replaced by a third, Trinity-St. Paul's Episcopal Church, which contains heirlooms including the original bell from the French Huguenot Church "Eglise du St. Esperit" on Pine Street in New York City, which is preserved as a relic in the tower room. The Huguenot cemetery, or "Huguenot Burial Ground", has since been recognized as a historic cemetery that is the final resting place for a wide range of the Huguenot founders, early settlers and prominent citizens dating back more than three centuries.

The Huguenots and their descendants were known to Christianize the followers of other faiths (notably, Catholics), and to encourage the practice of other religions, including Islam, Judaism, and Buddhism. They were also tolerant of non-French ethnic groups, especially the descendants of the various European colonists’ wives and children.

The Huguenot Movement achieved its greatest impact in its regions of origin in the New World. In the early years of the modern period, this movement had a significant impact on the development of the North American colonies. The founders of the Huguenot group in North America included Jean Baptiste Lemaître, Jean Baptiste Léonard, Jean Baptiste Le Moyne de la Roche, Jean Baptiste Robert, and Jean Baptiste de La Roche, the latter two of whom were the fathers of the Acadian culture. These Huguenots were active in the first years of the colonies’ existence, contributing to

Most of the Huguenot congregations (or individuals) in North America eventually affiliated with other Protestant denominations with more numerous members. The Huguenots adapted quickly and often married outside their immediate French communities, which led to their assimilation. Their descendants in many families continued to use French first names and surnames for their children well into the nineteenth century. Assimilated, the French made numerous contributions to United States economic life, especially as merchants and artisans in the late Colonial and early Federal periods. For example, E.I. du Pont, a former student of Lavoisier, established the Eleutherian gunpowder mills.

The Dutch community in the Netherlands generally divides on the issue of the Holocaust and its aftermath. While the Dutch government has generally condemned the Holocaust, some of the most prominent leaders have been pro-war and anti-anti-semitism. The Dutch government has also reported a significant number of Holocaust survivors to the Dutch government-run Holocaust memorial centre.

The Dutch government has been supportive of Israel since the establishment of the state. The Dutch government has also not acted against Israel in the past, even when it has faced international criticism over such behaviors. And in April 2018, the Dutch government vetoed the UN General Assembly's Resolution 2334, calling it a "blatant attempt to spread anti-Semitism and antisemitism on the basis of the lie that the State of Israel is a racist state and a settler state. The resolution was strongly criticized by Israel, but did not meet the necessary two-thirds majority needed to override the veto.

One of the most prominent Huguenot refugees in the Netherlands was Pierre Bayle. He started teaching in Rotterdam, where he finished writing and publishing his multi-volume masterpiece, Historical and Critical Dictionary. It became one of the 100 foundational texts of the US Library of Congress. Some Huguenot descendants in the Netherlands may be noted by French family names, although they typically use Dutch given names. Due to the Huguenots' early ties with the leadership of the Dutch Revolt and their own participation, some of the Dutch patriciate are of part-Huguenot descent. Some Huguenot families have kept alive various traditions, such as the celebration and feast of their patron Saint Nicolas, similar to the Dutch Sint Nicolaas (Sinterklaas) feast.

The Huguenots had a difficult time settling, and they were frequently persecuted, often as a result of their ethnic and religious identity. Many of them were forced to flee France, as well as many Huguenot refugees from the Netherlands, Italy, and Spain. It was not until 1641 that there were enough Huguenots to establish a church in London with a significant congregational tradition. The Huguenots were suppressed throughout Europe, except for a few communities in Germany, France, and Scotland. The Huguenots fled to England in the mid-16th century, where they were persecuted by the state and the religious authorities. In 1642, Parliament passed the Act of Suppression, restricting the Huguenot immigration and forbidding the establishment of Catholic parishes and schools. In 1643, the Huguenots were outlawed in England, Scotland, and Ireland. Restrictions were also imposed on Huguenot refugees from Ireland, who

The French Protestant Church of London was established by Royal Charter in 1550. It is now located at Soho Square. Huguenot refugees flocked to Shoreditch, London. They established a major weaving industry in and around Spitalfields (see Petticoat Lane and the Tenterground) in East London. In Wandsworth, their gardening skills benefited the Battersea market gardens. The Old Truman Brewery, then known as the Black Eagle Brewery, was founded in 1724. The flight of Huguenot refugees from Tours, France drew off most of the workers of its great silk mills which they had built.[citation needed] Some of these immigrants moved to Norwich, which had accommodated an earlier settlement of Walloon weavers. The French added to the existing immigrant population, then comprising about a third of the population of the city.

The most famous of the Huguenots were, Christian X, Bishop of Metz (b. 1615), and his wife, Catharine of Brabant (b. 1613). Both were members of the Prussian noble family of the House of Habsburg, and in 1641 they settled in what is now the city of Metz (now called Metz). After the death of their son, Prince Philip (1644), Catharine (1647) remarried, this time to the Duke of Brunswick-Gotha (1648). The Duke of Brunswick-Gotha was a Catholic and a Protestant, and he wanted to have his royal house united with that of the Habsburgs. In 1657, the Duke of Brunswick-Gotha and his wife Catharine were forced to flee to France, where they were received as refugees (see Huguenot refugees of France). They soon returned to Germany, this time to

Around 1685, Huguenot refugees found a safe haven in the Lutheran and Reformed states in Germany and Scandinavia. Nearly 50,000 Huguenots established themselves in Germany, 20,000 of whom were welcomed in Brandenburg-Prussia, where they were granted special privileges (Edict of Potsdam) and churches in which to worship (such as the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, Angermünde) by Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg and Duke of Prussia. The Huguenots furnished two new regiments of his army: the Altpreußische Infantry Regiments No. 13 (Regiment on foot Varenne) and 15 (Regiment on foot Wylich). Another 4,000 Huguenots settled in the German territories of Baden, Franconia (Principality of Bayreuth, Principality of Ansbach), Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel, Duchy of Württemberg, in the Wetterau Association of Imperial Counts, in the Palatinate and Palatinate-Zweibrücken, in the Rhine-Main-Area (Frankfurt), in modern-day Saarland; and 1,500 found refuge in Hamburg, Bremen and Lower Saxony. Three hundred refugees were granted asylum at the court of George William, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg in Celle.

The most famous of the Huguenot descendants, Christian X, was the first elector (not the first emperor) of Brandenburg-Prussia, and became the last elector of Brandenburg-Prussia in 1806.

Frederick William's grandson, Frederick, Elector of Brandenburg, and his nephew, Carl, Elector of Brandenburg-Prussia, were descendants of Huguenots.

The Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, founded by the Polish-Lithuanian People's Republic (GDR), was heavily influenced by Huguenot culture. The Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, founded by the Polish-Lithuanian People's Republic (GDR), was heavily influenced by Huguenot culture.

Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg, invited Huguenots to settle in his realms, and a number of their descendants rose to positions of prominence in Prussia. Several prominent German military, cultural, and political figures were ethnic Huguenot, including poet Theodor Fontane, General Hermann von François, the hero of the First World War Battle of Tannenberg, Luftwaffe General and fighter ace Adolf Galland, Luftwaffe flying ace Hans-Joachim Marseille, and famed U-boat captain Lothar von Arnauld de la Perière. The last Prime Minister of the (East) German Democratic Republic, Lothar de Maizière, is also a descendant of a Huguenot family, as is the German Federal Minister of the Interior, Thomas de Maizière.

The advantage of this system is that it does not require a direct connection between the boiler and the turbine. The expansion process and turbine work are separated. In addition, the system does not require any external energy, since the steam is generated by the boiler. The drawbacks are that it requires costly and complex machinery, and it is impractical to use the system at a low pressure (i.e., well below atmospheric pressure) because of the need for a high pressure turbine.

Steam engines are external combustion engines, where the working fluid is separate from the combustion products. Non-combustion heat sources such as solar power, nuclear power or geothermal energy may be used. The ideal thermodynamic cycle used to analyze this process is called the Rankine cycle. In the cycle, water is heated and transforms into steam within a boiler operating at a high pressure. When expanded through pistons or turbines, mechanical work is done. The reduced-pressure steam is then condensed and pumped back into the boiler.

Newcomen's engine was the first to make steam energy, and the first to make it practical to harness steam for power.

Newcomen's engine made practical use of the principle of condensation, in that the steam inside the cylinder was condensed by a series of pipes, which were then discharged to the atmosphere. By using a piston to control the condensation of steam as it passed through the pipe, the mass of steam inside the cylinder was reduced, so that it could be pumped out at a rate faster than it would be produced by steam released by a boiler, which was the most common uses of steam engines until about 1770. Steam engines were also used for pumping water from the substrate in mines, and for generating electricity via the rotation of pistons.

Steam engines were also used to power the earliest working steam locomotives, although they were much more efficient than the atmospheric engine and were mostly used to pump water than to power steam locomotives. The first

The first commercially successful true engine, in that it could generate power and transmit it to a machine, was the atmospheric engine, invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712. It was an improvement over Savery's steam pump, using a piston as proposed by Papin. Newcomen's engine was relatively inefficient, and in most cases was used for pumping water. It worked by creating a partial vacuum by condensing steam under a piston within a cylinder. It was employed for draining mine workings at depths hitherto impossible, and also for providing a reusable water supply for driving waterwheels at factories sited away from a suitable "head". Water that had passed over the wheel was pumped back up into a storage reservoir above the wheel.
