Consultant pharmacy practice focuses more on medication regimen review (i.e. "cognitive services") than on actual dispensing of drugs. Consultant pharmacists most typically work in nursing homes, but are increasingly branching into other institutions and non-institutional settings. Traditionally consultant pharmacists were usually independent business owners, though in the United States many now work for several large pharmacy management companies (primarily Omnicare, Kindred Healthcare and PharMerica). This trend may be gradually reversing as consultant pharmacists begin to work directly with patients, primarily because many elderly people are now taking numerous medications but continue to live outside of institutional settings. Some community pharmacies employ consultant pharmacists and/or provide consulting services.

The most basic difference between community pharmacies and Internet pharmacies is that the former are operated by local pharmacy groups while the latter are operated by individual patients. Patients who participate in these pharmacies have the opportunity to pick and choose their doctor based on their needs.

There are many different types of Internet pharmacies. Some of them are known as walled gardens while others are not. In a walled garden, the vendor is the only person who can respond to customers’ requests. In case of a drug shortage, the vendor can be the only one who can provide a generic, which is the most common type of drug that can be found on the market.

Since about the year 2000, a growing number of Internet pharmacies have been established worldwide. Many of these pharmacies are similar to community pharmacies, and in fact, many of them are actually operated by brick-and-mortar community pharmacies that serve consumers online and those that walk in their door. The primary difference is the method by which the medications are requested and received. Some customers consider this to be more convenient and private method rather than traveling to a community drugstore where another customer might overhear about the drugs that they take. Internet pharmacies (also known as online pharmacies) are also recommended to some patients by their physicians if they are homebound.

The Internet community has developed mechanisms to protect itself from illegal and unethical actions taken by pharmacies. (See: Protecting Yourself and Others from Pharmacies.)

Internet pharmacies have been subject to numerous lawsuits filed in state and federal court. Some of the suits have accused Internet pharmacies of violating various laws, including the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, the Federal Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act, the Controlled Substances Act, and the Pharmacy and Prescription Drug Monitoring Program Act.

Internet pharmacies have also been subject to a number of complaints filed by the United States Department of Health and Human Services.

Online pharmacies face many challenges in establishing a legitimate and ethical business. This is especially true for people who find it difficult to engage in in-person interactions with a doctor, such as patients. Many Internet pharmacies also have difficulty in maintaining a legitimate business model due to the high costs associated with marketing and advertising.

People who visit Internet pharmacies face

While most Internet pharmacies sell prescription drugs and require a valid prescription, some Internet pharmacies sell prescription drugs without requiring a prescription. Many customers order drugs from such pharmacies to avoid the "inconvenience" of visiting a doctor or to obtain medications which their doctors were unwilling to prescribe. However, this practice has been criticized as potentially dangerous, especially by those who feel that only doctors can reliably assess contraindications, risk/benefit ratios, and an individual's overall suitability for use of a medication. There also have been reports of such pharmacies dispensing substandard products.

For example, in states that require a prescription to be written, issued, maintained and revised by a physician, the filling pharmacy must ensure that the prescription is valid and valid physician-patient relationship established with the patient is in place. In other states, a patient may obtain a prescription from a filling pharmacy and the pharmacy may issue a valid prescription without the prescription being written by a physician.

Since the Internet is uncensored, any content on the Internet may be accessible by anyone with the right to see it, including anyone in the United States. For example, a person who enters a drugstore without a prescription can view the contents of prescription bottle behind the pharmacy counter. The filling pharmacy has the responsibility to ensure that the prescription is valid, which may be difficult given the wide variety of drugs available and the wide range of population that is online. Of particular concern with Internet pharmacies is the ease with which people, youth in particular, can obtain controlled substances (e.g., Vicodin, generically known as hydrocodone) via the Internet without a prescription issued by a doctor/practitioner who has an established doctor-patient relationship. There are many instances where a practitioner issues a prescription, brokered by an Internet server, for a controlled substance to a "patient" s/he has never met.[citation needed] In the United States, in order for a prescription for a controlled substance to be valid, it must be issued for a legitimate medical purpose by a licensed practitioner acting in the course of legitimate doctor-patient relationship. The filling pharmacy has a corresponding responsibility to ensure that the prescription is valid. Often, individual state laws outline what defines a valid patient-doctor relationship.

Pharmacy informatics is the combination of pharmacy practice science and applied information science. Pharmacy informaticists work in many practice areas of pharmacy, however, they may also work in information technology departments or for healthcare information technology vendor companies. The University of California at San Francisco has a unique approach to understanding specialty pharmacies and their impact on the pharmaceutical industry. The university has partnered with specialty pharmacy management company The Pharmacy Group to conduct a study that will allow the university to analyze specialty pharmacy data across the country. The study will follow nearly 16,000 patients and track the development of their therapeutic needs over time. For every patient, the study will be able to provide an individualized treatment plan.

Specialty pharmacies supply high cost injectable, oral, infused, or inhaled medications that are used for chronic and complex disease states such as cancer, hepatitis, and rheumatoid arthritis. Unlike a traditional community pharmacy where prescriptions for any common medication can be brought in and filled, specialty pharmacies carry novel medications that need to be properly stored, administered, carefully monitored, and clinically managed. In addition to supplying these drugs, specialty pharmacies also provide lab monitoring, adherence counseling, and assist patients with cost-containment strategies needed to obtain their expensive specialty drugs. It is currently the fastest growing sector of the pharmaceutical industry with 19 of 28 newly FDA approved medications in 2013 being specialty drugs.

In some rural areas in the United Kingdom, there are dispensing physicians who are allowed to both prescribe and dispense prescription-only medicines to their patients from within their practices. The law requires that the GP practice be located in a designated rural area and that there is also a specified, minimum distance (currently 1.6 kilometres) between a patient's home and the nearest retail pharmacy. This law also exists in Austria for general physicians if the nearest pharmacy is more than 4 kilometers away, or where none is registered in the city.

The most basic rule of medicine is that the physician, as the sole professional authority, has a responsibility to the patient. The physician is the first line of defense in the patient-physician relationship. The physician is the individual who has the most direct control over the patient. It is the physician's duty to act with the best interests of the patient at heart. It is the physician's duty to discern the patient's needs and to provide the most appropriate treatment.

However, this principle is not absolute. The physician has a responsibility to act in the patient's best interest, regardless of the legal or ethical implications. This includes considerations such as the likelihood of a conflict of interest, the amount of risk the patient would be willing to take, and the likelihood that the patient would be willing to accept an alternative treatment for the same condition. In addition, the physician should never have an "affirmative obligation" to any one patient.

In some cases, this principle may

The reason for the majority rule is the high risk of a conflict of interest and/or the avoidance of absolute powers. Otherwise, the physician has a financial self-interest in "diagnosing" as many conditions as possible, and in exaggerating their seriousness, because he or she can then sell more medications to the patient. Such self-interest directly conflicts with the patient's interest in obtaining cost-effective medication and avoiding the unnecessary use of medication that may have side-effects. This system reflects much similarity to the checks and balances system of the U.S. and many other governments.[citation needed]

Research on MTM has been conducted in recent years, and has been shown to be an effective way to increase patient satisfaction and improve health outcomes. However, pharmacists are significantly underrepresented as participants in these studies.

The purpose of this study is to address this issue, and to identify the needs of pharmacists participating in MTM studies. A qualitative survey of nearly 100 pharmacists in the United States was conducted. The researchers found that pharmacists reported not having access to the material needed to participate in MTM studies. This lack of access was a barrier to participation in MTM studies. Specifically, pharmacists expressed concern that the MTM literature was not readily available, and that the amount of literature available was insufficient.

The researchers recommended that pharmacists be included in MTM studies. The best way for pharmacists to learn about MTM literature is to read it, and to read and share it with their colleagues.

In the coming decades, pharmacists are expected to become more integral within the health care system. Rather than simply dispensing medication, pharmacists are increasingly expected to be compensated for their patient care skills. In particular, Medication Therapy Management (MTM) includes the clinical services that pharmacists can provide for their patients. Such services include the thorough analysis of all medication (prescription, non-prescription, and herbals) currently being taken by an individual. The result is a reconciliation of medication and patient education resulting in increased patient health outcomes and decreased costs to the health care system.

Research on community pharmacies

Community pharmacies are often seen as a critical component in community health (notably, in the U.S., they are seen as a primary or secondary point of contact for many people for health-related issues), as many people do not have a doctor or other medical professional to refer them to for their health needs. Community pharmacies offer a variety of services, and in some regions, they are considered a primary source of health care for the elderly.

Despite their many benefits, community pharmacies continue to be under attack from some policy makers. This includes claims of overstocking and understaffing, and the fact that they are not licensed to dispense medications prescribed by physicians. This is especially true in the case of home-based pharmacies, in which pharmacists are not licensed to dispense controlled substances.

The two symbols most commonly associated with pharmacy in English-speaking countries are the mortar and pestle and the ℞ (recipere) character, which is often written as "Rx" in typed text. The show globe was also used until the early 20th century. Pharmacy organizations often use other symbols, such as the Bowl of Hygieia which is often used in the Netherlands, conical measures, and caduceuses in their logos. Other symbols are common in different countries: the green Greek cross in France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India, the increasingly rare Gaper in the Netherlands, and a red stylized letter A in Germany and Austria (from Apotheke, the German word for pharmacy, from the same Greek root as the English word 'apothecary').

The most famous recent example of civil disobedience on a global scale was the "Occupy" (or "Oblivion") movement in 2011. In November 2011, Occupy Wall Street protesters were met with overwhelmingly violent police repression.

Civil disobedience refers to non-violent, non-violent resistance to authority and injustice. This is in contrast to criminal disobedience, which is when people deliberately break the law, such as striking or burning a police station, or breaking into a hospital to steal a patient's medicine.

History

The oldest known form of civil disobedience was the act of civil disobedience by the Egyptian Revolution of 1919. Egypt's leaders planned to rewrite the constitution to allow the monarchy, which had been in power since 1882, to remain in power. On October 22, a massive wave of protests spread from Tahrir Square to the capital, Cairo. The protests were organized under the slogan "down with the king!" and consisted of both students and workers. The Egyptian

One of its earliest massive implementations was brought about by Egyptians against the British occupation in the 1919 Revolution. Civil disobedience is one of the many ways people have rebelled against what they deem to be unfair laws. It has been used in many nonviolent resistance movements in India (Gandhi's campaigns for independence from the British Empire), in Czechoslovakia's Velvet Revolution and in East Germany to oust their communist governments, In South Africa in the fight against apartheid, in the American Civil Rights Movement, in the Singing Revolution to bring independence to the Baltic countries from the Soviet Union, recently with the 2003 Rose Revolution in Georgia and the 2004 Orange Revolution in Ukraine, among other various movements worldwide.

One of the oldest depictions of civil disobedience is in Sophocles' play Antigone, in which Antigone, one of the daughters of former King of Thebes, Oedipus, defies Creon, the current King of Thebes, who is trying to stop her from giving her brother Polynices a proper burial. She gives a stirring speech in which she tells him that she must obey her conscience rather than human law. She is not at all afraid of the death he threatens her with (and eventually carries out), but she is afraid of how her conscience will smite her if she does not do this.

The Masque of Anarchy is generally considered the first, and perhaps the most thought-provoking, statement of the principle of nonviolent protest. The image of the masked anarchist is an iconic image of the movement, since it was a common sight at the time. The images of the dead were especially disturbing to British and French soldiers, who were already afraid of the anarchist movement. The image of the masked anarchist, the mass of dead bodies, and the motif of the mask reveal the underlying material causes of the violence in the society. The image of the masked anarchist was one of the inspirations for the film of the same name, which was directed by John Sturges. The film introduced the world to Shelley's poetry and, most importantly, to the idea that violence cannot be seen as abstract and universal. The symbolism of the mask is one of the most well-known symbols of anarchism, and it is often referred to in the name of the movement.

Following the Peterloo massacre of 1819, poet Percy Shelley wrote the political poem The Mask of Anarchy later that year, that begins with the images of what he thought to be the unjust forms of authority of his time—and then imagines the stirrings of a new form of social action. It is perhaps the first modern[vague] statement of the principle of nonviolent protest. A version was taken up by the author Henry David Thoreau in his essay Civil Disobedience, and later by Gandhi in his doctrine of Satyagraha. Gandhi's Satyagraha was partially influenced and inspired by Shelley's nonviolence in protest and political action. In particular, it is known that Gandhi would often quote Shelley's Masque of Anarchy to vast audiences during the campaign for a free India.

The most basic term in this debate is "lawlessness." The same applies to "civil disobedience," but the context is important. The term "lawlessness" can be applied to any criminal activity that is not undertaken in the lawful manner, as the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and the Civil Rights Act of 1867, all of which achieved great successes in protecting Americans from discrimination, have been demonstrated.

In the situation of civil disobedience, the operative question is not whether the activity is lawful or illegal. It is whether the activity is lawful or unlawful. We can say that the Civil Liberties Act of 1971, which eliminated the concept of "lawful" and "unlawful" conduct, has made it clear that it is lawful and lawful to protest laws. The same applies for the other civil liberties legislation that have been enacted. The right to protest is a fundamental right enshrined in the Constitution.

It has been argued that the term "civil disobedience" has always suffered from ambiguity and in modern times, become utterly debased. Marshall Cohen notes, "It has been used to describe everything from bringing a test-case in the federal courts to taking aim at a federal official. Indeed, for Vice President Agnew it has become a code-word describing the activities of muggers, arsonists, draft evaders, campaign hecklers, campus militants, anti-war demonstrators, juvenile delinquents and political assassins."

The most basic distinction between lawful protest demonstration, nonviolent civil disobedience, and violent civil disobedience is the purpose of the protest. Protest is a form of expression that is simply done because it is socially necessary. It is an expression of a feeling, a belief, a desire, a hope, a grievance, a demand, a desideratum, or a wish. It is a statement of fact in its own right, without the aid of extraneous information, or of a statement of opinion. It is a statement of fact in the same sense as the statement "I do not like this! This is wrong!"

Violent protest is a form of protest that is intended to accomplish some end. It is a form of protest that is carried out in order to achieve a specific objective, and it is an action that is intended to achieve that objective.

It is not a question of whether or not a person is validly protesting. Whether or not a person is validly protesting

LeGrande writes that "the formulation of a single all-encompassing definition of the term is extremely difficult, if not impossible. In reviewing the voluminous literature on the subject, the student of civil disobedience rapidly finds himself surrounded by a maze of semantical problems and grammatical niceties. Like Alice in Wonderland, he often finds that specific terminology has no more (or no less) meaning than the individual orator intends it to have." He encourages a distinction between lawful protest demonstration, nonviolent civil disobedience, and violent civil disobedience.

The most basic definition of civil disobedience is as follows: refusing to perform a lawful duty. (The legal term for this action is "civil disobedience.") In most contexts, civil disobedience is a form of protest, since the individual is protesting the government of the country. For instance, the civil disobedience of a protestor demonstrating against the Vietnam War would not be considered civil disobedience, as he or she was exercising an constitutionally protected right.

The principle of civil disobedience, however, differs from the principle of protest in that it is a matter of behaviors. And in order to be considered civil disobedience, the individual must be a citizen. A member of the military, a police officer, or a government employee cannot be considered civil disobedience. A person of any other status cannot be considered civil disobedience.

Civil disobedience is a legal concept that was developed in the United States in the 1960s to deal with the civil rights struggle of the 1960s. Civil disobedience was first outlined in a 1963

Civil disobedience is usually defined as pertaining to a citizen's relation to the state and its laws, as distinguished from a constitutional impasse in which two public agencies, especially two equally sovereign branches of government, conflict. For instance, if the head of government of a country were to refuse to enforce a decision of that country's highest court, it would not be civil disobedience, since the head of government would be acting in her or his capacity as public official rather than private citizen.

The most basic rule of political philosophy is that the state must exist for the people, by the people, for the people and not for the state. In other words, the people must be empowered to exercise their own political freedom. But the need for government to be a form of tyranny must be understood in terms of a particular historical context. In the days of the Roman Empire, the people exercised little political power. The imperial government, on the other hand, had the powers of the Roman Republic, which had been established in the wake of the fall of the Roman Empire.

In short, the people were ruled by a government and its actions were dictated by the government. Because of the dependence on government, the people could not really assert their own political freedom. In fact they could not even assert their own freedom for that matter. The people were dependent on the government to provide the means for them to live. Thus, the Roman Empire had the same problems with tyranny as we have

However, this definition is disputed by Thoreau's political philosophy pitching the conscience vs. the collective. The individual is the final judge of right and wrong. More than this, since only individuals act, only individuals can act unjustly. When the government knocks on the door, it is an individual in the form of a postman or tax collector whose hand hits the wood. Before Thoreau’s imprisonment, when a confused taxman had wondered aloud about how to handle his refusal to pay, Thoreau had advised, “Resign.” If a man chose to be an agent of injustice, then Thoreau insisted on confronting him with the fact that he was making a choice. But if government is “the voice of the people,” as it is often called, shouldn’t that voice be heeded? Thoreau admits that government may express the will of the majority but it may also express nothing more than the will of elite politicians. Even a good form of government is “liable to be abused and perverted before the people can act through it.” Moreover, even if a government did express the voice of the people, this fact would not compel the obedience of individuals who disagree with what is being said. The majority may be powerful but it is not necessarily right. What, then, is the proper relationship between the individual and the government?

The most basic rule of civil disobedience is that you, as a non-violent person, must not cause disruption to the normal functioning of the state. That is, you should not try to make your way onto a bridge or a highway, or make your way onto a public street, or try to block traffic in a parking lot. You should not, for example, break into a bank in order to collect the money it is owed.

The legal community generally disagrees about whether or not a suspect's refusing to talk to police officers (or to any other person) is a valid grounds for arrest. This disagreement is rooted in the fact that police officers are not trained to arrest people for not talking to them. On the other hand, the legal community holds that police officers must have the authority to arrest someone who refuses to answer questions in order to collect the necessary evidence to charge them. In other words, police officers are not required to make a specific arrest to collect evidence.

The legality of a criminal act

In criminal law, the legality of a criminal act is determined by the circumstances of the act, as well as the intent of the criminal. In practice, this means that a person cannot be criminally punished for something he did not know he was doing.

Many of the same decisions and principles that apply in other criminal investigations and arrests arise also in civil disobedience cases. For example, the suspect may need to decide whether or not to grant a consent search of his property, and whether or not to talk to police officers. It is generally agreed within the legal community, and is often believed within the activist community, that a suspect's talking to criminal investigators can serve no useful purpose, and may be harmful. However, some civil disobedients have nonetheless found it hard to resist responding to investigators' questions, sometimes due to a lack of understanding of the legal ramifications, or due to a fear of seeming rude. Also, some civil disobedients seek to use the arrest as an opportunity to make an impression on the officers. The legitimacy of the social contract

Some civil disobedients feel it is incumbent upon them to accept punishment because of their belief in the validity of the social contract, which is held to bind all to obey the laws that a government meeting certain standards of legitimacy has established, or else suffer the penalties set out in the law. Other civil disobedients who favor the existence of government still don't believe in the legitimacy of their particular government, or don't believe in the legitimacy of a particular law it has enacted. And still other civil disobedients, being anarchists, don't believe in the legitimacy of any government, and therefore see no need to accept punishment for a violation of criminal law that does not infringe the rights of others.

The most basic rule of civil disobedience is that you, as a person, have the right to decide what is right and wrong. The law does not have the right to decide for you; therefore, if you are arrested, you must assert that the law is wrong. If you are arrested, you must assert that the police are wrong, and that your rights are violated. If you are arrested and charged, the police have a duty to respond to your situation reasonably, and to not use excessive force. You may continue to assert your rights as long as it does not violate other individuals' rights or the rights of others.

You have the right to refuse to participate in a lawful police action, or to refuse to yield to authority when lawfully requested. You have the right to challenge the laws being enforced, and the legal basis of those laws. You have the right to challenge the legality of the actions of the police. You have the right to refuse to answer a lawful question.

An important decision for civil disobedients is whether or not to plead guilty. There is much debate on this point, as some believe that it is a civil disobedient's duty to submit to the punishment prescribed by law, while others believe that defending oneself in court will increase the possibility of changing the unjust law. It has also been argued that either choice is compatible with the spirit of civil disobedience. ACT-UP's Civil Disobedience Training handbook states that a civil disobedient who pleads guilty is essentially stating, "Yes, I committed the act of which you accuse me. I don't deny it; in fact, I am proud of it. I feel I did the right thing by violating this particular law; I am guilty as charged," but that pleading not guilty sends a message of, "Guilt implies wrong-doing. I feel I have done no wrong. I may have violated some specific laws, but I am guilty of doing no wrong. I therefore plead not guilty." A plea of no contest is sometimes regarded as a compromise between the two. One defendant accused of illegally protesting nuclear power, when asked to enter his plea, stated, "I plead for the beauty that surrounds us"; this is known as a "creative plea," and will usually be interpreted as a plea of not guilty.

When the Committee for Non-Violent Action sponsored a protest in August 1957, at the Camp Mercury nuclear test site near Las Vegas, Nevada, 13 of the protesters attempted to enter the test site knowing that they faced arrest. At a pre-arranged announced time, one at a time they stepped across the "line" and were immediately arrested. They were put on a bus and taken to the Nye County seat of Tonopah, Nevada, and arraigned for trial before the local Justice of the Peace, that afternoon. A well known civil rights attorney, Francis Heisler, had volunteered to defend the arrested persons, advising them to plead "nolo contendere", as an alternative to pleading either guilty or not-guilty. The arrested persons were found "guilty," nevertheless, and given suspended sentences, conditional on their not reentering the test site grounds.[citation needed]

Some civil disobedience defendants choose to make a defiant speech, or a speech explaining their actions, in allocution. In U.S. v. Burgos-Andujar, a defendant who was involved in a movement to stop military exercises by trespassing on U.S. Navy property argued to the court in allocution that "the ones who are violating the greater law are the members of the Navy". This action was upheld because, according to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, her statement suggested a lack of remorse, an attempt to avoid responsibility for her actions, and even a likelihood of repeating her illegal actions. The Constitution guarantees the right to a jury trial, even if the defendant seeks to avoid conviction. A jury trial is required for a criminal defendant to have a constitutional right to a jury trial. This is especially true for federal crimes. Steven Barkan writes that if defendants plead not guilty, "they must decide whether their primary goal will be to win an acquittal and avoid imprisonment or a fine, or to use the proceedings as a forum to inform the jury and the public of the political circumstances surrounding the case and their reasons for breaking the law via civil disobedience." A technical defense may enhance the chances for acquittal but make for more boring proceedings and reduced press coverage. During the Vietnam War era, the Chicago Eight used a political defense, while Benjamin Spock used a technical defense. In countries such as the United States whose laws guarantee the right to a jury trial but do not excuse lawbreaking for political purposes, some civil disobedients seek jury nullification. Over the years, this has been made more difficult by court decisions such as Sparf v. United States, which held that the judge need not inform jurors of their nullification prerogative, and United States v. Dougherty, which held that the judge need not allow defendants to openly seek jury nullification.

The most basic rule of civil disobedience is that you, as a person, must not commit a crime. That is, if you are acting on behalf of a group, or for yourself as an individual, you must not commit a crime. The exception to this rule is if, for example, you’re a police officer who breaks the law, or a soldier who breaks the law in order to collect the surrender of a rebel. In these cases, you are violating the civil disobedience rules, even if you did not commit a crime.

The consequences of breaking the law can be severe: people can be imprisoned, and even be beheaded. This is why civil disobedience is often associated with radical leftists and anarchists: they are the only ones who can engage in civil disobedience, and they can break the law for the sake of doing so.

It would not be necessary to break civil disobedience rules for everyone to be a conscientious lawbreaker; indeed, a great many people

One theory is that, while disobedience may be helpful, any great amount of it would undermine the law by encouraging general disobedience which is neither conscientious nor of social benefit. Therefore, conscientious lawbreakers must be punished. Michael Bayles argues that if a person violates a law in order to create a test case as to the constitutionality of a law, and then wins his case, then that act did not constitute civil disobedience. It has also been argued that breaking the law for self-gratification, as in the case of a homosexual or cannabis user who does not direct his act at securing the repeal of amendment of the law, is not civil disobedience. Likewise, a protestor who attempts to escape punishment by committing the crime covertly and avoiding attribution, or by denying having committed the crime, or by fleeing the jurisdiction, is generally viewed as not being a civil disobedient.

The legal community has traditionally been more receptive to the arguments of the legal defense. The American Bar Association has also become more favorable to the legal defense of eco-activists.

As of November 2006, according to the National Coalition Against Censorship, scores of criminal cases involving climate change-related protests and civil disobedience have been brought to the courts in the United States. In 2002, the National Law Review reported that "at least" 2,759 cases had been filed in federal courts in the United States alleging violations of the First Amendment against the climate change movement, including claims of criminal conduct, civil disobedience and political speech.

Courts have distinguished between two types of civil disobedience: "Indirect civil disobedience involves violating a law which is not, itself, the object of protest, whereas direct civil disobedience involves protesting the existence of a particular law by breaking that law." During the Vietnam War, courts typically refused to excuse the perpetrators of illegal protests from punishment on the basis of their challenging the legality of the Vietnam War; the courts ruled it was a political question. The necessity defense has sometimes been used as a shadow defense by civil disobedients to deny guilt without denouncing their politically motivated acts, and to present their political beliefs in the courtroom. However, court cases such as U.S. v. Schoon have greatly curtailed the availability of the political necessity defense. Likewise, when Carter Wentworth was charged for his role in the Clamshell Alliance's 1977 illegal occupation of the Seabrook Station Nuclear Power Plant, the judge instructed the jury to disregard his competing harms defense, and he was found guilty. Fully Informed Jury Association activists have sometimes handed out educational leaflets inside courthouses despite admonitions not to; according to FIJA, many of them have escaped prosecution because "prosecutors have reasoned (correctly) that if they arrest fully informed jury leafleters, the leaflets will have to be given to the leafleter's own jury as evidence."

The most basic rule of criminal punishment is that no one is to be punished more than once (not even once for the same crime). This is a basic rule of human nature, but as Leonard Hubert Hoffmann argues, "Humans need not be punished more than once, but must be punished” (21-22). A second rule, therefore, is that "punishment is only a last resort" (Hoffmann, 1990, p. 7).

The question then becomes, "Does the punishment fit the crime?" Here it is important to note that the criminal law uses the word "punishment" to describe actions that are usually considered to have a negative moral effect on the offender and, most importantly, to indicate that the punishment should be seen as having a positive moral effect on the population at large.

For example, it would not be appropriate to punish a child for an accident. It would be appropriate, however, to punish this child for

Along with giving the offender his "just deserts", achieving crime control via incapacitation and deterrence is a major goal of criminal punishment. Brownlee argues, "Bringing in deterrence at the level of justification detracts from the law’s engagement in a moral dialogue with the offender as a rational person because it focuses attention on the threat of punishment and not the moral reasons to follow this law." Leonard Hubert Hoffmann writes, "In deciding whether or not to impose punishment, the most important consideration would be whether it would do more harm than good. This means that the objector has no right not to be punished. It is a matter for the state (including the judges) to decide on utilitarian grounds whether to do so or not."

Under this system, once the design is completed by the design team, a number of construction companies or construction management companies may then be asked to make a bid for the work, either based directly on the design, or on the basis of drawings and a bill of quantities provided by a quantity surveyor. Following evaluation of bids, the owner typically awards a contract to the most cost efficient bidder.

The advantage of this contract is that it allows for faster time to market and lower costs. The alternative to the design-build contract is a build-operate-own (BOO) contract where the contractor is able to be given a performance specification but is required to complete the construction phase of the project himself. The modern trend in design is toward integration of previously separated specialties, especially among large firms. In the past, architects, interior designers, engineers, developers, construction managers, and general contractors were more likely to be entirely separate companies, even in the larger firms. Presently, a firm that is nominally an "architecture" or "construction management" firm may have experts from all related fields as employees, or to have an associated company that provides each necessary skill. Thus, each such firm may offer itself as "one-stop shopping" for a construction project, from beginning to end. The financial problems that can arise from these types of situations are often complex and difficult to solve. There are several methods that can be used to mitigate potential problems and ensure that the project is as cost-effective as possible. In general, the first step to a successful project is to ensure that adequate funding is available and that the project is adequately budgeted. This is often achieved with a project plan. A project plan is an essential step in the financial planning process.

Project plans may include many different parts, and many of them should be reviewed together. They include the following types of information:

Business plan: This is a very thorough and detailed business plan that will be essential in the early phase of development, and will be required of any project that is financed in the future.

Project budget: This is the amount of money that is available to complete the project, and it should be carefully reviewed in the business plan.

Force majeure insurance: This

Construction projects can suffer from preventable financial problems. Underbids happen when builders ask for too little money to complete the project. Cash flow problems exist when the present amount of funding cannot cover the current costs for labour and materials, and because they are a matter of having sufficient funds at a specific time, can arise even when the overall total is enough. Fraud is a problem in many fields, but is notoriously prevalent in the construction field. Financial planning for the project is intended to ensure that a solid plan with adequate safeguards and contingency plans are in place before the project is started and is required to ensure that the plan is properly executed over the life of the project.

The financial management of the building construction project requires the cooperation of the owners and the contractor. The mortgage banker is often involved and has a vested interest in the quality of the project. The accountants and cost engineers are interested in the value of the building and are also likely participants in the financial management of the project. The cost engineer is engaged to prepare a detailed cost estimate for the project and is well-versed in the strategies for controlling costs throughout the project.

The most basic set of contracts is the purchase agreement, and the most basic set of contracts is the sale agreement. These two types of contracts are often used interchangeably, but there are important distinctions. The purchase agreement sets out what the buyer expects to get, and the sale agreement sets out what the seller expects to get. This is the core of the transaction, and it is important to set out clearly what the buyer expects to get and what the seller expects to get. The sale agreement should also be written in English, because the buyer is likely to want bilingual assistance, and the seller is likely to want English assistance.

There are two basic types of contracts: an access agreement and a confidentiality agreement. The access agreement is the exchange of information between two parties, and they are typically exchanged in writing. The confidentiality agreement is the exchange of information regarding the specific contracts of interest, and it is often exchanged in writing.

Cases of construction contracts are a bit tricky.

A construction project is a complex net of contracts and other legal obligations, each of which all parties must carefully consider. A contract is the exchange of a set of obligations between two or more parties, but it is not so simple a matter as trying to get the other side to agree to as much as possible in exchange for as little as possible. The time element in construction means that a delay costs money, and in cases of bottlenecks, the delay can be extremely expensive. Thus, the contracts must be designed to ensure that each side is capable of performing the obligations set out. Contracts that set out clear expectations and clear paths to accomplishing those expectations are far more likely to result in the project flowing smoothly, whereas poorly drafted contracts lead to confusion and collapse.

Research on community-based procurement has also noted that, as the economy improves, community-based approaches to procurement become more and more prevalent. This is seen as an important factor for the sustainable development of these communities since the procurement is intended to be responsive to their needs.

Governments have also been increasingly involved with the procurement of construction projects. For example, in 2012, the United Kingdom and Sweden announced the opening of a "Cross-Government Procurement (CGP) Partnership" to improve the efficiency and transparency of the UK procurement system. And in April 2013, the United States Department of Energy (DOE) announced the establishment of a Task Force on Community-Based Procurement with the goal of addressing community concerns and encouraging innovative and sustainable approaches to procurement in the United States.

Funding for community-based procurement has also increased. In the United States, the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program has spent almost $1 billion on this initiative since

There is also a growing number of new forms of procurement that involve relationship contracting where the emphasis is on a co-operative relationship between the principal and contractor and other stakeholders within a construction project. New forms include partnering such as Public-Private Partnering (PPPs) aka private finance initiatives (PFIs) and alliances such as "pure" or "project" alliances and "impure" or "strategic" alliances. The focus on co-operation is to ameliorate the many problems that arise from the often highly competitive and adversarial practices within the construction industry.

The most common term for this type of construction is, "estimated delivery." The architect (or engineer) generates the plans and specifications, and prepares the specifications, which are collected in a bid. The main contractor submits a bid for the works to be performed. The architect or engineer then creates a construction schedule, with the estimated delivery date as the first item. The estimate is then used to sign the contract.

The contract is written in such a way that the architect may not make changes to the estimate or to the specifications. The main contractor may make changes only after the architect or the client has given the main contractor all the necessary information. Changes include but are not limited to:

Scheduling: The contractor must submit a project schedule for the works. The contract specifies the work to be performed and the work to be finished. The schedule must include a detailed description of the work to be performed.

This is the most common method of construction procurement and is well established and recognized. In this arrangement, the architect or engineer acts as the project coordinator. His or her role is to design the works, prepare the specifications and produce construction drawings, administer the contract, tender the works, and manage the works from inception to completion. There are direct contractual links between the architect's client and the main contractor. Any subcontractor has a direct contractual relationship with the main contractor. The procedure continues until the building is ready to occupy.

The advantage of this contract is that it allows for faster time to market and lower costs. (The disadvantage is that the owner has to be involved in every stage of the project, including design, construction, and operation.)

Why is it better to do a design-bid-build?

Design-bid-build allows the owner to maximize the value of their project, and in turn save money.

Design-bid-build is well suited for small to mid-size projects, where the owner's expertise and experience can be an important asset. This is because the owner is the ultimate expert in the project.

Design-bid-build is also well suited for projects where phase 1 is already underway. This is because it allows the owner to control the scope of the project and complete the project in a predictable and orderly way.

Design-bid-build is also well suited for projects where the owner wants to save money by minimizing costs. For example

The owner produces a list of requirements for a project, giving an overall view of the project's goals. Several D&B contractors present different ideas about how to accomplish these goals. The owner selects the ideas he or she likes best and hires the appropriate contractor. Often, it is not just one contractor, but a consortium of several contractors working together. Once these have been hired, they begin building the first phase of the project. As they build phase 1, they design phase 2. This is in contrast to a design-bid-build contract, where the project is completely designed by the owner, then bid on, then completed.

As of 2005, there were about 667,000 firms employing 1 million contractors (200,000 general contractors, 38,000 heavy, and 432,000 specialty); the average contractor employed fewer than 10 employees. As a whole, the industry employed an estimated 5.8 million as of April 2013, with a 13.2% unemployment rate. In the United States, approximately 828,000 women were employed in the construction industry as of 2011.

Research on average salaries in the construction industry has shown, that the UK’s construction industry is still relatively young. The industry is still in its infancy and construction workers have many career options.

In 2010 a salary survey revealed the differences in remuneration between different roles, sectors and locations in the construction and built environment industry. The results showed that areas of particularly strong growth in the construction industry, such as the Middle East, yield higher average salaries than in the UK for example. The average earning for a professional in the construction industry in the Middle East, across all sectors, job types and levels of experience, is £42,090, compared to £26,719 in the UK. This trend is not necessarily due to the fact that more affluent roles are available, however, as architects with 14 or more years experience working in the Middle East earn on average £43,389 per annum, compared to £40,000 in the UK. Some construction workers in the US/Canada have made more than $100,000 annually, depending on their trade.

Research on construction sites can be difficult to conduct due to the site's remote location, the large number of workers, and the risk of injury. Nevertheless, understanding construction site accidents and injuries can lead to safer construction practices. In a survey of 7,351 construction sites reported in Canada, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) found that, in 2010, nearly 16,000 injuries and 16,700 deaths occurred on construction sites. In 2010, approximately 7,000 of these injuries and deaths occurred in Canada's construction industry. Construction site fatalities are a major cause of occupational injuries and deaths in the U.S. and Canada. In 2010, the construction industry lost 7,000 workers in the U.S. and over 2,000 workers in Canada. Additionally, OSHA estimates that an additional 14,000 work-related injuries occur each year in the construction industry, and approximately 1,000 work-related injuries occur each day.

In a recent study,

Construction is one of the most dangerous occupations in the world, incurring more occupational fatalities than any other sector in both the United States and in the European Union. In 2009, the fatal occupational injury rate among construction workers in the United States was nearly three times that for all workers. Falls are one of the most common causes of fatal and non-fatal injuries among construction workers. Proper safety equipment such as harnesses and guardrails and procedures such as securing ladders and inspecting scaffolding can curtail the risk of occupational injuries in the construction industry. Other major causes of fatalities in the construction industry include electrocution, transportation accidents, and trench cave-ins.

The most basic term for this type of school is, “independent”, but the term “non-government” school is also used. Schools are typically large, with numerous buildings and classrooms.

The most important difference between government and non-government schools is that government schools’ standards are often stricter than non-government schools. According to a US Department of Education study, students in government schools may have higher average SAT scores, grade point averages, and ACT scores than those in non-government schools. Government schools have also been known to give more emphasis to academic achievement, while non-government schools have been known to give more emphasis to extracurricular activities.

There are many types of schools, from urban to rural, religious to secular, and more. The best way for you to find the best schools for your child is to visit the school yourself and speak to the teachers, students and parents.

Things to know about private schools

Private schools, also known as independent schools, non-governmental, or nonstate schools, are not administered by local, state or national governments; thus, they retain the right to select their students and are funded in whole or in part by charging their students tuition, rather than relying on mandatory taxation through public (government) funding; at some private schools students may be able to get a scholarship, which makes the cost cheaper, depending on a talent the student may have (e.g. sport scholarship, art scholarship, academic scholarship), financial need, or tax credit scholarships that might be available.

The term 'tuition-free' has no legal meaning. In addition, it is not a legal requirement for students to pay tuition to attend unaccredited schools (as there is no legal obligation for students to pay school tuition). Furthermore, many private schools are not accredited, and most have no accreditation standards at all.

The term 'tuition-free' is also used in the United States in the context of people who pay for their education, but whose parents may not be able to afford to pay for their education. For example, a student who serves as an honor society member at his/her university.

In the United Kingdom and several other Commonwealth countries including Australia and Canada, the use of the term is generally restricted to primary and secondary educational levels; it is almost never used of universities and other tertiary institutions. Private education in North America covers the whole gamut of educational activity, ranging from pre-school to tertiary level institutions. Annual tuition fees at K-12 schools range from nothing at so called 'tuition-free' schools to more than $45,000 at several New England preparatory schools.

Background
In the 1970s, the Canadian government started a large-scale residential school project and a residential school massacre in the late 1970s.

As of November 2006, according to Statistics Canada, the largest number of residential schools reported by Canada was in Northern Ontario (538), with the second largest number of residential schools (254) in Alberta and Saskatchewan.

The mass grave of 215 people was discovered on the site of the former Kamloops Indian Residential School in British Columbia. On June 28, 2018, a joint investigation by the Globe and Mail and the Toronto Star revealed that more than 300 unmarked graves from the former Kamloops school have been found. This is the most mass grave discovery of its kind in Canadian history and the largest of its kind in North America.

In August 2018, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada (TRCC) released the results of an investigation into the residential school system in Canada.

The secondary level includes schools offering years 7 through 12 (year twelve is known as lower sixth) and year 13 (upper sixth). This category includes university-preparatory schools or "prep schools", boarding schools and day schools. Tuition at private secondary schools varies from school to school and depends on many factors, including the location of the school, the willingness of parents to pay, peer tuitions and the school's financial endowment. High tuition, schools claim, is used to pay higher salaries for the best teachers and also used to provide enriched learning environments, including a low student to teacher ratio, small class sizes and services, such as libraries, science laboratories and computers. Some private schools are boarding schools and many military academies are privately owned or operated as well.

Research on religious education in the US
In the 1970s, religion became a dominant topic in the education research. One of the first to do so was Professor Leonard Friedman, who published a book called The Religious Education of American Children. His research focused on the educational practices of children of various religions. He conducted interviews with teachers and parents, and studied the books of religious leaders as well as the school curriculums of the various religious groups. In his book, Friedman critiqued the idea that religious education should be taught to children in school, arguing that it should be provided after the children leave the classroom. In the 1980s, another author, Frank N. Zappa, followed the same path. His book, The Religious Education of American Children: A Survey of the Characteristics of Religious Education, was the first study to evaluate religious instruction in the United States. The author interviewed teachers, parents and students from religious schools, and found that the religious education was a very important part

Religiously affiliated and denominational schools form a subcategory of private schools. Some such schools teach religious education, together with the usual academic subjects to impress their particular faith's beliefs and traditions in the students who attend. Others use the denomination as more of a general label to describe on what the founders based their belief, while still maintaining a fine distinction between academics and religion. They include parochial schools, a term which is often used to denote Roman Catholic schools. Other religious groups represented in the K-12 private education sector include Protestants, Jews, Muslims and the Orthodox Christians.

Research on the effect of private schools on the performance of their pupils has shown mixed results. Some researchers have found that private schools improve student achievement. Other research has found no or only a slight effect of private schools on student achievement.

Private schools are often accused of having a negative impact on the quality of education provided to their students, and of encouraging inequality. However, as with any other school, the quality of education provided depends on the quality of resources available, and the learning environment. In addition, the quality of resources available may be adversely affected by competition for the resources available, and by the lack of funding available for education and other activities.

Private schools in Australia may be favoured for many reasons: prestige and the social status of the 'old school tie'; better quality physical infrastructure and more facilities (e.g. playing fields, swimming pools, etc.), higher-paid teachers; and/or the belief that private schools offer a higher quality of education. Some schools offer the removal of the purported distractions of co-education; the presence of boarding facilities; or stricter discipline based on their power of expulsion, a tool not readily available to government schools. Student uniforms for Australian private schools are generally stricter and more formal than in government schools - for example, a compulsory blazer. Private schools in Australia are always more expensive than their public counterparts.[citation needed]

Research on 'elite schools'
In the 1970s, the Australian Public Policy Institute (APPI) undertook a study of elite school enrolments in Australia, which was collected in a book called The Elite School System – A Study of The Early Years. This study prompted a number of responses from various organisations and individuals with different opinions, so it was not a representative study of the overall population.

The study was a series of interviews with parents, students, teachers, administrators and professional critics of the elite schools. The interviews were conducted between April and July 1978, and the data was used to produce a report entitled The Elite School System – A Study of The Early Years.

The largest phase of the study was the 1970s, and it was concluded that in the 1970s, the elite schools attracted only about 7% of the total enrolments in the country. The proportion of enrolments in the elite schools decreased progressively from 3.3% in 1975 to 1.

Ersatzschulen are ordinary primary or secondary schools, which are run by private individuals, private organizations or religious groups. These schools offer the same types of diplomas as public schools. Ersatzschulen lack the freedom to operate completely outside of government regulation. Teachers at Ersatzschulen must have at least the same education and at least the same wages as teachers at public schools, an Ersatzschule must have at least the same academic standards as a public school and Article 7, Paragraph 4 of the Grundgesetz, also forbids segregation of pupils according to the means of their parents (the so-called Sonderungsverbot). Therefore, most Ersatzschulen have very low tuition fees and/or offer scholarships, compared to most other Western European countries. However, it is not possible to finance these schools with such low tuition fees, which is why all German Ersatzschulen are additionally financed with public funds. The percentages of public money could reach 100% of the personnel expenditures. Nevertheless, Private Schools became insolvent in the past in Germany.

The most basic term Ergänzungs, means "version" or "second", "version" is used to refer to the first edition of the textbook (first edition is called Ergänzungsschulen-1). The second edition was written, compiled and edited by a different person and is called Ergänzungsschulen-2.

Etymology of the word "Ergänzungsschule"

The origin of the word "Ergänzungsschule" is uncertain, but the title of the book Ergänzungsschule II, published in 1868, is related to the word "erga" (Latin for "second", "second edition"), which means "to print". The word "Ergänzung" itself is derived from the Latin "ergare", "to print", and "ga" (Latin for "second", "second edition").

Ergänzungsschulen are secondary or post-secondary (non-tertiary) schools, which are run by private individuals, private organizations or rarely, religious groups and offer a type of education which is not available at public schools. Most of these schools are vocational schools. However, these vocational schools are not part of the German dual education system. Ergänzungsschulen have the freedom to operate outside of government regulation and are funded in whole by charging their students tuition fees.

In Ireland, private schools (Irish: scoil phríobháideach) are unusual because a certain number of teacher's salaries are paid by the State. If the school wishes to employ extra teachers they are paid for with school fees, which tend to be relatively low in Ireland compared to the rest of the world. There is, however, a limited element of state assessment of private schools, because of the requirement that the state ensure that children receive a certain minimum education; Irish private schools must still work towards the Junior Certificate and the Leaving Certificate, for example. The average fee is around €5,000 annually for most schools, but some of these schools also provide boarding and the fees may then rise up to €25,000 per year. The fee-paying schools are usually run by a religious order, i.e., the Society of Jesus or Congregation of Christian Brothers, etc.

The most recent private school numbers have also seen a decline. In 2011, there were 78 private schools in New Zealand. In 2013, there were 71 private schools, down from 83 in 2010.

As of April 2014, there are 88 private schools in New Zealand, catering for around 28,000 students or 3.7% of the entire student population. Private school numbers have been in decline since the mid-1970s as a result of many private schools opting to become state-integrated schools, mostly due of financial difficulties stemming from changes in student numbers and/or the economy. State-integrated schools keep their private school special character and receives state funds in return for having to operate like a state school, e.g. they must teach the state curriculum, they must employ registered teachers, and they can't charge tuition fees (they can charge "attendance dues" for the upkeep on the still-private school land and buildings). The largest decline in private school numbers occurred between 1979 and 1984, when the nation's then-private Catholic school system integrated. As a result, private schools in New Zealand are now largely restricted to the largest cities (Auckland, Hamilton, Wellington and Christchurch) and niche markets.

The most recent set of private schools to be included in the list are those operated by the Anglican Communion. These include The Royal High School in Wellington and the New Zealand College in Christchurch. Both were previously part of The Anglican Theological College.

The most common term for this type of school is, and has been for many years, "Independent School". This name and term is often used unspecifically, but is generally understood to refer to these schools.

The term "private school" has also been applied, though not in the same way, to schools with religious, social or philosophical policies. However, as these schools are privately owned, they are not regulated by the Education Act 1996, so are not regulated by this legislation.[citation needed] This is a matter of debate. Some privately owned schools are regulated by the Annual Education Regulations (England) 2000.

The Independent Schools Council is the organisation which funds and regulates independent schools in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. It is responsible for reviewing and approving the fees and charges for independent schools for the following year and for setting fees for the following year. The Council also regulates and sets the fees of schools on the basis of the quality of the educational standards achieved

Private schools generally prefer to be called independent schools, because of their freedom to operate outside of government and local government control. Some of these are also known as public schools. Preparatory schools in the UK prepare pupils aged up to 13 years old to enter public schools. The name "public school" is based on the fact that the schools were open to pupils from anywhere, and not merely to those from a certain locality, and of any religion or occupation. According to The Good Schools Guide approximately 9 per cent of children being educated in the UK are doing so at fee-paying schools at GSCE level and 13 per cent at A-level.[citation needed] Many independent schools are single-sex (though this is becoming less common). Fees range from under £3,000 to £21,000 and above per year for day pupils, rising to £27,000+ per year for boarders. For details in Scotland, see "Meeting the Cost".

The most famous of the private schools was the "Black Christian Academy" (BCA), founded in 1960 by Dr. James R. King. BCA's mission was to educate children with a Christian worldview, according to King.

The BCA's first year of operation was in 1960. King's vision was to open a "school of learning", where "the virtues of Christianity would be taught uncorrupted and the virtues of the Human Sciences would not be corrupted."[4] Students at BCA were taught to be "progressive, creative, bilingual" and to "believe without doubt in God and the Bible".[4] King envisioned a school that would have a high graduation rate, which he believed would be a good way to "re-integrate" the United States into the rest of the world.[4]

In many parts of the United States, after the 1954 decision in the landmark court case Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka that demanded United States schools desegregate "with all deliberate speed", local families organized a wave of private "Christian academies". In much of the U.S. South, many white students migrated to the academies, while public schools became in turn more heavily concentrated with African-American students (see List of private schools in Mississippi). The academic content of the academies was usually College Preparatory. Since the 1970s, many of these "segregation academies" have shut down, although some continue to operate.[citation needed]

The most basic question is this:

Are religious schools (as defined by the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment and Blaine Amendments) entitled to government funding (as defined by the Establishment Clause and Blaine Amendments)? If so, how much?

One answer, which has been widely accepted for decades, is "no."

In recent years, however, some courts have been divided on the question. In a case called Corbett v. Barnhart, the Supreme Court reversed a lower court decision in favor of a private Christian school by finding that the school was entitled to public funding because it had a religious purpose and was thus entitled to federal funding.

Why the Supreme Court decided this way, and why it overturned a lower court decision, is a story for another day. The best explanation for the Corbett decision is that the Corbett case was a landmark case in which the Supreme Court effectively eliminated the possibility of religious schools receiving government funding.

But

Funding for private schools is generally provided through student tuition, endowments, scholarship/voucher funds, and donations and grants from religious organizations or private individuals. Government funding for religious schools is either subject to restrictions or possibly forbidden, according to the courts' interpretation of the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment or individual state Blaine Amendments. Non-religious private schools theoretically could qualify for such funding without hassle, preferring the advantages of independent control of their student admissions and course content instead of the public funding they could get with charter status.

The Supreme Court has not addressed whether private schools can discriminate against children based on race, color, creed, national origin, and other characteristics. The potential for discrimination in private schools appears real; there is ample evidence of systemic discrimination.

State-mandated scores reported by private schools are often poor indicators of student achievement. This is because these scores, while often representative of a school's academic performance, are not necessarily reflective of a school's educational potential for students. The tests measure only a small percentage of the knowledge and skills a student can develop. And privately-run schools tend to have lower levels of test preparation programs, which are often based on standardized testing.

Private schooling in the United States has been debated by educators, lawmakers and parents, since the beginnings of compulsory education in Massachusetts in 1852. The Supreme Court precedent appears to favor educational choice, so long as states may set standards for educational accomplishment. Some of the most relevant Supreme Court case law on this is as follows: Runyon v. McCrary, 427 U.S. 160 (1976); Wisconsin v. Yoder, 406 U.S. 205 (1972); Pierce v. Society of Sisters, 268 U.S. 510 (1925); Meyer v. Nebraska, 262 U.S. 390 (1923).

The most basic question to ask is: How can we reduce the cost of educating our children? There are several ways.

First, we need to empower teachers to teach, not to be the gatekeepers of the school.

Second, we need to create a culture of learning in the classroom.

Third, we need to train teachers to teach.

Fourth, we need to collect the data needed to evaluate each child and make well-informed decisions about where to send them.

Fifth, we need to build an infrastructure of schools, including after-school programs, where parents can bring their children and be assured that there will be teachers, books, and learning materials.

Sixth, we need to create incentives and engage parents in the education of their children.

The bottom line is that we need to empower teachers to teach, not to be the gatekeepers of the school.

As of 2012, quality private schools in the United States charged substantial tuition, close to $40,000 annually for day schools in New York City, and nearly $50,000 for boarding schools. However, tuition did not cover operating expenses, particularly at boarding schools. The leading schools such as the Groton School had substantial endowments running to hundreds of millions of dollars supplemented by fundraising drives. Boarding schools with a reputation for quality in the United States have a student body drawn from throughout the country, indeed the globe, and a list of applicants which far exceeds their capacity.

The Harvard community is divided into two main groups: Harvardians (those who hold a University (not Harvard) faculty or staff appointment, and affiliated faculty members) and Harvardians-in-residence (those who are not affiliated faculty members or staff members, but who live, work, and attend classes at Harvard). Harvardians-in-residence are often referred to as "Harvardians," while Harvardians are generally referred to as "Harvardians." Harvardians have an established identity within the community and many of them have formal affiliations with Harvard. Harvardians-in-residence maintain individual identities separate from the community and are often referred to as "Harvardians-in-residence." In most cases, this distinction is maintained by the professional institutions they work at, but some Harvardians-in-residence also maintain personal affiliations with Harvard.

Established originally by the Massachusetts legislature and soon thereafter named for John Harvard (its first benefactor), Harvard is the United States' oldest institution of higher learning, and the Harvard Corporation (formally, the President and Fellows of Harvard College) is its first chartered corporation. Although never formally affiliated with any denomination, the early College primarily trained Congregationalist and Unitarian clergy. Its curriculum and student body were gradually secularized during the 18th century, and by the 19th century Harvard had emerged as the central cultural establishment among Boston elites. Following the American Civil War, President Charles W. Eliot's long tenure (1869–1909) transformed the college and affiliated professional schools into a modern research university; Harvard was a founding member of the Association of American Universities in 1900. James Bryant Conant led the university through the Great Depression and World War II and began to reform the curriculum and liberalize admissions after the war. The undergraduate college became coeducational after its 1977 merger with Radcliffe College.

Research
The term research is generally used on campus, and outside of campus, it usually refers to academics performing research. Research at Harvard often focuses on biological and social sciences, engineering, and medicine. Harvard's academic research is collaborative, with a large number of students, faculty, and staff participating in projects that ultimately lead to the discovery, development, and dissemination of new knowledge.

Harvard is home to more than a dozen research institutes and centers, including the Harold C. Lawrence Center for Brain Science, the W. M. Keck Center for Biomedical Engineering, the School of the Museum of Mechanical Engineering, and the Harvard School of Public Health. The Institute of Politics and International Affairs (IPIA) is a faculty-led center that examines the intersection of politics and international affairs. The Institute of the Environment is a teaching and research institute that focuses on the environment, including natural and human-induced climate change, and the impact of human activity on the environment. Harvard is a large, highly residential research university. The nominal cost of attendance is high, but the University's large endowment allows it to offer generous financial aid packages. It operates several arts, cultural, and scientific museums, alongside the Harvard Library, which is the world's largest academic and private library system, comprising 79 individual libraries with over 18 million volumes. Harvard's alumni include eight U.S. presidents, several foreign heads of state, 62 living billionaires, 335 Rhodes Scholars, and 242 Marshall Scholars. To date, some 150 Nobel laureates, 18 Fields Medalists and 13 Turing Award winners have been affiliated as students, faculty, or staff.

Research
The term research is generally used on campus, and is commonly used to indicate research (not necessarily applied science) and computing research in particular. Research is typically done through large-scale projects in laboratories, by independent researchers, or by collaborative research projects with other institutions. It is also often done in graduate and post-doctoral education, which may be in small or large laboratories, and in large-scale computing projects.

The university has several well-known and highly regarded research programs, including the Applied Mathematics and Statistics Research Group (AMSIG), the Center for Computational Linguistics (CCL), the Computational History Research Group (CHRG), the Computational Linguistics Research Group (CLRG), the Center for Computational Mathematics and Statistics (CMASH), the Computational History Research Group (CHRG), and the Harvard Center for Systems Biology (HCBS).

Harvard's $37.6 billion financial endowment is the largest of any academic institution.

The first English term for the college was "Academy" (1637; "Archaic College"). Harvard and other English universities did not have formal faculties (as distinct from departments) until the mid-17th century. The first faculty member to be named a full professor was John Mason in 1738. By the 1760s, Harvard had a faculty of 16 professors and 200 students. In the 18th century, Harvard was known for its liberal arts curriculum, and for its literary club, the Harvard Club. Harvard also produced many notable students, including the scholars Charles Dickens, John Greenleaf Whittier, and Edmund Burke.

The campus contains an array of buildings, including Cambridge House, the oldest building on the campus, which was constructed in 1606 to accommodate a group of Massachusetts Bay Colony governors. Harvard was formed in 1636 by vote of the Great and General Court of the Massachusetts Bay Colony. It was initially called "New College" or "the college at New Towne". In 1638, the college became home for North America's first known printing press, carried by the ship John of London. In 1639, the college was renamed Harvard College after deceased clergyman John Harvard, who was an alumnus of the University of Cambridge. He had left the school £779 and his library of some 400 books. The charter creating the Harvard Corporation was granted in 1650.

The College was set up as a private institution for men. It was not affiliated with any particular denomination but had Puritan and Unitarian leaders. It was never affiliated with any particular denomination, but many of its earliest graduates went on to become clergymen in Congregational and Unitarian churches.

The College was founded in 1642 by the Puritan William Courtenay, and in 1646, the first female students began to attend. For the next century, the College was a private institution for men. This changed in 1685, when it was incorporated as a public institution for women, and in 1699, when all its students were women. In the 18th century the college was also a women's college.

It has, however, a mind of its own, and it is engaged in activities, such as learning, as well as in thoughts. In the mass of matter there are innumerable ideas, which are acted upon by the material body, and are transmitted to it by the matter. These ideas are called 'inhabitants' or'memories.' They are found all over nature, from the smallest to the largest organisms. The largest organisms, such as insects, are the most intelligent.
